Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Huseyn

texts.ru: Хусенов Хусейн проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 56 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Образование средне - специальное, шофер. По профессии проработал 10 лет. Сейчас он работает на рынке. Готовит пирожки и самбусу для продажи. В этом ему помогает жена. Имеет богатый опыт в этой сфере. Кредит берет для расширения сферы деятельности, то есть он хочет взять в аренду помещение и открыть хлебопекарню.
texts.en:
Huseyn H. lives in Vahdat. He is 56 years old, married, and has three children. He has a vocational education as a driver. He worked in his trade for ten years. Now he works in the market. He makes pies and sambusas (savory filled pies) for sale. His wife helps him. He has vast experience in this. He is taking out a loan to expand his business. He wants to lease a space and open a bakery.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Odette

texts.en:
Odette is 34 years old and married with three children who are  2, 7 and 9 years old.  Odette makes a living by selling a variety of goods in her small shop as her picture indicates.  Odette has been in this business for about five years and the hours of her business are from 6 am to 7 pm every day.

Although Odette has been in this business for about five years, her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully.  To end this, she needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, she will invest in the sale of foodstuffs mainly cassava, Irish potatoes, potatoes, beans, etc.  With these foodstuffs, Odette will hopefully earn a lot of profit and this profit will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs including cassava, Irish potatoes, potatoes, beans, etc

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda T. is from the village of Bagong Sikat, Alicia, Isabela. She is 50 years old, married and has 4 adult children. Imelda owns & operates a livestock business, raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells a raised animal.

In 2006, Imelda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Imelda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros P. is from the village of Bayabo East. She is 47 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Milagros owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP during the harvest season.

In 2007, Milagros joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. She is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Milagros from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Vasila

texts.ru: Шарипова Васила проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 54 года. Замужем, имеет 8 детей. Образование высшее, педагог. По специальности работала 15 лет. Сейчас она занимается торговлей. У нее магазин, где она продает заколки, бижутерии и много разной мелочи. В этой области уже 13 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота. На полученную прибыль она хочет женить сына.
texts.en:
Vasila S. lives in Yavan. She is 54 years old, married, and has eight children. She has a higher education as a teacher. She worked in her specialty for fifteen years. Now she is works in sales. She has a shop where she sells hairpins, costume jewelry, and various knick-knacks. She has been doing this for thirteen years. She is taking out a loan to increase sales. With her profits, she would like to marry off her son.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing sales

loans.name: Arsenio

texts.en:
Arsenio Y. is from the village of Bayabo East. He is 53 years old, married and has 4 adult children. Arsenio owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over 29 years and earns approximately 45,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2007, Arsenio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Arsenio is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Arsenio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Nabingola Dembe Group, Mubende

texts.en: J. Stephan is the leader of his lending group in Mubende. He is 35 years old, married and has 5 children, 4 of whom go to school. He also takes care of dependants. Stephan sells maize, beans and cassava from Nabingola and Kibaale in a roadside market. Stephan is committed and honest and in a month he is able to make a profit of 360,000/=. Stephan is also a farmer and he needs a loan to support his business of 10 years that has been a family venture from the very start. He needs a loan to buy more beans and maize for resale.

loans.use: to buy more beans and maize for resale.

loans.name: Joyeuse

texts.en:
Joyeuse is 43 years and married.  Joyeuse is commonly known for selling a variety of school and office items.  She has been in this business for about five years and the hours of the business are from 8 am to 6 pm every day.

Joyeuse needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business.  With this loan, Joyeuse will purchase more office as well as school items with the purpose of satisfying the demands of her customers.  If successful, Joyeuse will earn a lot of money, which in turn will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loans.use: To buy a variety of office and school items

loans.name: Abunzubumwe No 2 Group

texts.fr:
Kanyamahamga Simeon née a bugesera l’Est du pays, marié,il a 3 enfants,il a 36 ans, son ainé a 10  ans et son 3.5 ans et  son niveau d’éducation est primaire. Il vit avec sa famille à sake Bugesera. 2 parmi ses enfants vont à l’école. Avec son mari ils travaillent pour faire vivre et améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. il fait le commerce des habits dans le centre commercial de Sake qui est un centre rural mais qui commence à être développé.

Il appartient dans un groupe solidaire appelé ABUNZUBUMWE NO 2,  qui est un groupe dont les membres sont  agri-éleveurs et ils se garantissent mutuellement, Simeon et son groupe travaillent pour faire vivre leurs familles en améliorant leurs conditions de vie et en amenant leurs enfants à l’école. En fait, le groupe a contracté un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Banking pour acheter les articles de leur commerce et les revendre, une partie du profit est  réinvesti pour maintenir la stabilité financière du groupe et épargner afin de préparer pour un bon futur.
texts.en:
Simeon Kanyamahamga was born in Bugesera in the eastern part of the country. He is married and has 3 children. He is 36 years old. His eldest child is 10 years old and his youngest is 3 and a half years old. He has a primary level of education. He lives with his family in Sake Bugesera. 2 of his children attend school. He works with his husband to provide for his family and improve its living conditions. He sells clothes at Sake’s commercial center. Although it is a rural center, it is starting to grow. He belongs to a solidarity group called ABUNZUBUMWE NO 2. The members of this group are farmers who mutually guarantee each other. Simeon and his group work to improve their families’ living conditions and send their children to school. The group has contracted a loan within the Amasezerano Community Banking association to purchase the goods necessary to their business and sell them. Part of the profit is reinvested in order to maintain the financial stability of the group and save money in order to prepare for a good future.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clothes for retail

loans.name: C4561 Twuzuzanye Group

texts.en:
Eugenie is 43 years old and married with three children. The first child is 20 years old, the next is 15 and the last is 11 years old. Eugenie takes care of one dependent who is 10 years. Eugenie owns a small business selling various styles of clothes. Eugenie has enough experience in this field because this is her fifth year of experience. The hours of her shop are from 8 in the morning to 7 in the evening every day except one day in the week. Eugenie is group leader of her group, which is called TWUZUZANYE in the local language. This group contains 11 members with different businesses.

Now, Eugenie and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their business through purchasing more products for their business. With this loan, Eugenie and her group will be able to satisfy their customers, which will be one of the ways of earning more profits.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Aydin

texts.ru:
Ayidn A. jenat i imeyet 2 detey. Emu 52 qoda. Aydin pereselenec iz okupirovannoy territorii Azerbaydjana, oblasti Kalbadjar i seychas obosnovalsya v Khirdalane. 

Eto vtoroye obrasheniye Aydina. On ochen blaqodaren za pervuyu ssudu v kotorom on prosil 1000 $ chtobi uvelichit pomesheniye eqo maqazina.
No teper Aydin otkril kafe uje 2 qoda. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit stoli i stulya dlya svoyeqo kafe.
texts.en:
Aydin A. is married with two children. He is 52 years old. Aydin is a refugee from an occupied territory in Azerbaijan, region of Kalbadjar, and now lives in Khirdalan. This is Aydin’s second loan. He is very grateful for the first loan in which he requested $1000 in order to expand his store. Aydin opened a café two years ago. Now he needs 2000 AZN to buy tables and chairs for his café.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying tables and chairs

loans.name: Nabingola Dembe Group B, Mubende

texts.en: S. Jamadah is the leader of his lending group in Mubende. He is 30 years old, married  and has 4 children, 3 of whom go to school. He also takes care of dependants. Jamadah sells maize and beans from the roadside market in Nabingola. Jamadah also sells cattle that he buys from the villages and sells to the township for meat and rearing. He is a committed and honest man and, in a month, he is able to make a profit of 190,000/= from produce and cattle sales. Jamadah felt that this was the easiest and most convenient business for him to do and does not regret his decision to do this. He needs a loan to be able to buy more beans and maize for resale. He believes that this will help him pay his children’s school fees as he has managed to build a house out of his savings.

loans.use: to buy more beans and maize for resale.

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn A. is from the village of Brgy. Lantap, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 32 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Roselyn owns & operates a livestock business, raising ducks to produce and sell eggs. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1,200 PHP a month.

In 2010, Roselyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Roselyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to financially support her immediate family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Bombooti Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BOMBOOTI a vu le jour depuis la création du Banc Villageois il ya 9 ans. Il fait partie du Banc Villageois de NEMA2. Il est composé de 05 femmes du même quartier. Il a pour but de renforcer la solidarité de groupe en particulier et de s'entraider entre membre en cas de difficulté de remboursement en général.

Madame Georgette KALAMON à l’extrême droite de la photo est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 47 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 09 enfants en charge.

Elle envisage de vendre des légumes. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité. Elle compte s'approvisionner à Ziguinchor et revend sa marchandise à domicile au marché Tiléne dans le département de Ziguinchor. 

Son nouveau crédit de 250.000 francs CFA lui permettra d’acheter de choux pommé, de carottes, de navets, de piments etc.

Son objectif est de développer son activité. Appuyer son mari sur les charges familiales tout en renforçant son niveau d’épargne.
texts.en:
The BOMBOOTI group was formed when the Banc Villageois of NEMA2 was created nine years ago. It consists of five women from the same neighborhood. Specifically, its goal is to strengthen the bond of solidarity within the group and more generally, for the members to help each other in case of difficulties with loan repayment. Mrs. Georgette KALAMON, at the far right of the photo, is the head of the group. She is 47 years old. She is married and a mother to nine dependent children. She plans to sell vegetables. She has good experience in this field. She expects to get her stocks in Ziguinchor for resale at her local market in Tiléne, in the Ziguinchor department. Her new loan of 250,000F CFA will allow her to buy cabbage, carrots, turnips, peppers, etc. Her goal is to expand her business, help her husband with the family’s expenses, and increase her savings.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables

loans.name: Muhammed

texts.en:
He is hilarious and always keeps a sparkly smile on his face. B. Muhammed, 43, is a happily married father of 8 and has been successfully overseeing his retail shop in Kimenyedde-Kayunga for the past 20 years. The decisions he has taken in regard to strengthening the smooth running of his business have had a big impact and explain why he has been able to achieve this longevity. He has educated all his children with profits from this business. 


What started off as a small shop is now a fully-fledged, flourishing, retail shop that brings him 300,000 shillings a month. The fact that he has been able to create and strike a pleasant working relationship with his clients also explains his success. His plans for the future are to expand his business into wholesale and to give his children the best possible education they can have. 


With this loan, Muhammed wants to purchase an array of general stock for his shop. In the villages commodities like soap, sugar, salt, candles, paraffin and bread are favorites. That is predominantly what he is planning to purchase with this loan.

loans.use: to purchase stock for resale

loans.name: Hien's Group

texts.en:
Hien T. N. is 35 years old. She lives in Pho Cho village with her husband and two children. She is a farmer. She not only grows rice but she sells porridge in the market. She has had this job for many years. She has a monthly income of about 2,500,000 Vietnamdong (VND) or 3,000,000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2007. She feels happy because she can save money every day, every week. The last cycle, she borrowed 4,578,000 VND and has completely repaid this amount punctually. Now she would like to borrow 5,886,000 VND to expand her shop. She is the leader of a five–member group loan from SEDA.

 About other borrowers in her group:

 Trang T. H. H. is 24 years old. She sells souvenier presents. She would like to borrow 6,758,000 VND to expand her shop.
 Vinh T. T. is 54 years old. She sells pork in the market. She would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND to invest in her business.
 Dung T. P. N. is 25 years old. She would like to borrow 5,886,000 VND to breed pigs.
 H. T. H. is 42 years old. She would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND to breed poultry.

loans.use: To expand her shop

loans.name: C4577 Abanyamurava Group

texts.en:
Solange is 26 years old and married with two children who are 2 and 4 years old. Solange is the leader of a group called Abanyamurava and this group is commonly known for selling foodstuffs.  This is their third successful year in this business and the business hours are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.

After three years of experience in the business, their capital is still too low to expand meaningfully.  To end this, they need to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company and this loan will allow them to increase the quantity of their sales as well as the profits.  If successful, this team will keep reinvesting and start saving for a better future for their business as well as their families.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs such as potatoes, beans, Irish potatoes, rice, etc...

loans.name: Nassinkar Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité de NASSINKAR est créé depuis la mise en place du Banc Villageois de NEMA2. Il est composé de six femmes du même et de même. Elles se sont organisées en groupe depuis l'inauguration du Banc Villageois pour renforcer leur solidarité et leur amitié. 
Madame Marie Pierre M. tout à fait à droit de la photo est la responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 50ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 08 enfants et a la charge de 03 autres enfants. 
Elle a 09 fois de fois de suite reçu de crédit auprès de CAURIE-MICRO FINANCE.
Elle fait un petit commerce de légumes. Elle achète des carottes, des choux, des navets etc..
Avec son prêt elle va renforcer son niveau d’approvisionnement en achetant plus de légumes et escompter des bénéfices plus importants.
Elle participe à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille par la nourriture, la santé, l’habillement et le payement de la scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
The Nassinkar solidarity group has been in existence since the Nema2 Banc Villageois was set up. It is made up of six women who are also members of the banc. When the banc was formed, they organized the group to strengthen their cooperation and their friendship. Mme Marie Pierre M., at extreme right in the photo, leads the group. She is 50. She is married, has eight children of her own and cares for three others. She has had nine loans from CAURIE Microfinance. She runs a small business in vegetables, buying carrots, cabbages, turnips and so on. With this loan she will build her inventory by buying more vegetables, and she hopes for increased profits to enable her to better meet her family's needs as far as food, health care, clothing and school fees are concerned.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Acheter des légumes

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Rosalina A.'s main source of income comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in her community. She is 62 years old, married and has six grown-up children. She is from the village of Brgy. Villa Coloma, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. Rosalina has been in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2006, Rosalina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase products to sell. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This will be her ninth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offerings

loans.name: Nayitna Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe NAYITNA a vu le jour depuis la création du Banc Villageois il y a 9ans. Il est composé de 04 femmes toutes issues du même quartier. Il a pour but de renforcer la solidarité l’entraide entre membre
Madame Simone D. à droite de la photo est responsable du groupe. Elle est vendeuse de légumes. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité. Elle s'approvisionne à Ziguinchor et revend sa marchandise à domicile et dans différents marchés de la ville 
Avec son prêt elle va acheter des choux, des carottes, des navets, tomates etc. 
Son objectif est de promouvoir son activité, de renforcer ses épargnes et de soutenir son mari dans les différentes charges familiales.
texts.en:
The group Nayitna came into being since the Banc Villageois was created nine years ago. It is composed of four women, all from the same district. Its goal is to bolster solidarity and the mutual aid among its members. Ms. Simone D. (at the right in the photo) is the group's leader. She is a seller of vegetables. She has good experience in this business domain. She stocks up in Ziguinchor and resells her merchandise out of her home and at the different markets in town. With her loan, Simone is going to buy some cabbage, carrots, turnips, tomatoes, etc. Her goal is to advance her business, to boost he savings, and to support her husband to cover the different family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying vegetables

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Being a loyal member of a Kiva first field partner in the Philippines (ASHI), Norma N. had been receiving loans since 2000. Loans she received then have enabled her to have several businesses that she managed. First, she started a cow & hog fattening business and with her next loans, she opened a party needs shop and rented sewing machines. To market her products, she sells directly to people in their village and in a public market. Now, Norma is requesting another loan from ASHI to support her businesses and to grow them further until such time that they become profitable and stable. For her party needs store, she wants to increase her inventory for the convenience of her customers who live around their village. 

Norma happily handles her career being a wife, mother and businesswoman. Her desire to give her children a better kind of life in the future inspired her to have her own businesses and augment her husband’s irregular income. 

Norma is one of the very good members of ASHI who is requesting a new loan of 45,000 PHP to realize her dream of buying more inventory for her party needs store and purchasing seven sewing machines to rent. Profit from these kinds of businesses is quite good compared to other businesses that Norma has tried. Because of the profits she gained from her businesses, Norma has enabled her two daughters to graduate with a degree. Additionally, she wants to support the education of her son through college so he has a better career in the future. With her passion for giving her children a better future, Norma is willing to work hard and help her husband earn money through her businesses. 

Norma is motivated by her desire for personal development so that one day she can be self-reliant in her businesses. Norma enjoys the system of work groups that is implemented by ASHI. She has benefited from hearing about the experiences of her fellow group members and appreciates that the process for securing a loan has been convenient for her.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her party needs store and purchase seven sewing machines to rent.

loans.name: Altannavch

texts.en:
Altannavch D. is 38 years old and lives with her parents and siblings in Baganuur, an outer district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a rented house. Altannavch operates a business where she sews traditional Mongolian and a variety of western clothes. She began her business in 2002 and, since then,  has become established in the local business community. She hopes to become even more successful so that she can provide for her family in the future. 

She is a responsible and honest woman and is requesting a 300,000 MNT loan so that she can purchase a sewing machine for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Sainte Jeanne D'arc Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SAINTE THÉRÈSE fait partie du Banc Villageois des femmes Catholiques de la Paroisse de LOUGA. Il est créé depuis trois ans. Il est composé de 12 femmes toutes issues de la même communauté ecclésiale de base. Elles sont très engagées dans les activités de la Paroisse.
Madame Élisabeth S., à droite de la photo est la présidente du groupe. Elle est âgée de 40ans. Elle est veuve et mère de 4 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois depuis son inauguration à l’instar de ses camarades
Elle fait un petit commerce de produits halieutiques, d’huile de palme et de jus de citron. Elle pratique cette activité depuis plus de 5ans.
Son lui permettra d’acheter des poissons séchés et/ou fumés, des huitres séchées, de l’huile de palme et du jus de citron.
Son objectif est de renforcer son activité. Elle prend l’entière charge de la nourriture, la santé et le payement de la scolarité de ses enfants
texts.en:
The solidarity group, Saint Therese, is part of the Village Bank of the Catholic women of the Louga Parish. It was created three years ago. It is made up of 12 women all coming from the same basic church community. They are very involved in the activities of the parish. Mrs. Élisabeth S., to the right of the photo, is the president of the group. She is 40 years old. She is widowed and the mother of 4 children. She has been a member of the Village Bank since its opening, following the example of her friends. She runs a small shop of fishing products, palm oil and lemon juice. She has run this business for more than 5 years. Her loan will allow her to buy dried and/or smoked fish, dried oysters, palm oil and lemon juice. Her goal is to strengthen her business. She is fully in charge of the food, health and school payments of her children.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy palm oil and lemon juice

loans.name: Jean Damascene

texts.en:
Jean damascene is 39 years old and married.  Jean damascene sells a variety of foodstuffs such as sorghum, beans, peas, maize, etc.  He has been in this business for about 10 years and the hours of his business are from 7 am to 8 pm every day.

Jean damascene needs to shift his business from his residential area to the main market.  To end this, he needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. This loan will allow him to purchase more foodstuffs for sale.  Jean damascene hopes that with the use of this loan, if he manages to go and operate his business in the main market, his profits will increase to the extent that the living style of his family will also improve.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of foodstuffs such as rice, maize, beans, etc

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice was born in 1975. She is married with two children. Alice owns a business selling various styles of clothes and traditional materials to be used for keeping milk and so on. This business is located in her residence. This is her fifth year of success in her business. The hours of her daily activities are from 7 in the morning to 6 in the evening every day.

Alice is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing her business. With this expansion, Alice will be able to satisfy her clients. Alice expects to earn more profit as long as her customers are satisfied. With this profit, hopefully, Alice will buy her own house.

loans.use: To buy different styles of clothes

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga S. is from the village of Mozzozzin Norte. She is 49 years old, married and has 8 school-aged children. Dominga owns & operates a manufacturing business, making & selling clay products to local businesses and community members. She has been engaged in her business for over 33 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Dominga joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. She is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be the third loan taken out by Dominga from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

loans.name: Mai's Group

texts.en:
Mai T. N. is 37 years old. She lives in Xom Huong village, Co Loa commune with her husband and two children. She and her husband are farmers. They grow rice and they also sell meat in the market. They have a monthly income of about 3,000,000 Vietamdong (VND). Mrs Mai has had this job for many years. She has participated in SEDA since 2005. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND for her business.
 
About other borrowers in her group:
 Chung T. N. is 58 years old, she would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND to breed poultry and raise vegetables.
 Toan T. N. is 58 years old. She has a store. She would like to borrow 5,886,000 VND to expand her store.

loans.use: to small business

loans.name: Bataa

texts.en:
Bataa N. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Baganuur, an outer district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. He and his family live together in their own apartment. His elder daughter is a student while his wife helps him with make traditional Mongolian shoes by hand.


He began his shoe making business in 2006 and his shoes are well known and valued by his customers for their quality and design. Bataa would eventually like to expand his shoe making business and create his own shop in the future. Bataa is an honest, reliable and hard working person who is requesting a 300,000 MNT loan to purchase materials for a large number of shoes.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Juma

texts.en:
Juma K. N. is a young man who runs his business in the Central Business District of Mombasa. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attractions, not forgetting the Indian Ocean white beaches. 


He sells mobile phone accessories and also does phone repairs. He has been in this business for three years now and he says that his business is very profitable. The major challenge that Juma has to deal with is limited space and power rationing. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more phone accessories to meet high customer demand. He hopes to grow his business and become a phone dealer, whereby, he will open many outlets and provide employment. He describes himself as a very social person.

loans.use: to buy phone accessories

loans.name: Mere Theresa Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité MÈRE THERESA fait partie du Banc Villageois des femmes Catholiques de la Paroisse de Louga. Il est créé depuis trois ans. il est composé de 11 femmes toutes du même quartier et de la même communauté ecclésiale de base. 
Madame Irène K. est la responsable du groupe. Elle est à l’extrême gauche de la photo. Elle est âgée de 53 ans. Elle est veuve et mère de 5 enfants et a la charge de 4 autres enfants.
Elle est restauratrice. Chaque soir elle se rend au foyer de la mission Catholique de Louga pour préparer et vendre de la soupe de viande de la grillade de viande. Elle prépare également des sandwichs et des poulets
Avec son prêt elle va augmenter son niveau d’approvisionnement en viande et en poulets et acheter plus de condiments. 
Elle prend entièrement toutes les charges familiales, nourriture, santé, habillement, scolarité etc.
texts.en:
The Mother Theresa solidarity group is part of the Banc Villageois of the Catholic Women’s association of the Louga parish. It has been created three years ago. It is composed of 11 women living in the same neighborhood and belonging to the same church community. Mrs. Irène Kampla is the group leaders. She is on the far left in the photo. She is 53 years old, a widow, the mother of five children, with four other children also in her care. She prepares food for sale. Each evening she comes to the parish house of the Catholic mission of Louga in order to cook meat soup and grill meats for sale. She also prepares sandwiches and cooks chicken. With this loan, she would like to expand her stock of meat and chicken and to purchase more condiments. She has full responsibility for all family expenses, such as food, healthcare, clothing, school fees etc.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing meat, chicken and food condiments

loans.name: Thoa

texts.en: Thoa T. K. T. is 53 years old. She is alone. She has broken her leg. She has a beverage store and her main income is profits from sales. She has an income of about 2,000,000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2004 and has always repaid punctually. She wants to borrow money form SEDA forever because, then, she can keep saving money. In her last cycle, she borrowed 7,630,000 VND and has completely repaid this amound. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,930,000 VND to expand her store.

loans.use: to expand her store

loans.name: Sanabarhon's Group

texts.en:
Sanabarhon S. is the leader of this group. She is 46 and is married. She has a son and two daughters, all of whom are of preschool age (in Kyrgyzstan children start school when they are seven).  Sanabarhon’s husband works in construction. When he is free he helps his wife with cattle breeding. They also own some land and cultivate different fruits and vegetables. Sanabarhon also sells dairy products every day. In this way she makes 2000 soms per month. With the loan she wants to purchase a cow and a calf for breeding.


Shairgul A., 31, is married. She has two sons and three daughters. All her children, apart from the youngest daughter, study at school. Shairgul’s husband sells fruit and vegetables wholesale and he makes 8000 soms per month. Shairgul breeds cattle. She applied for the loan because she wants to purchase a cow and a calf for breeding. In the future she wants to purchase a big truck to help her husband to start exportation of fruit and vegetables to neighboring countries.

Shairgul E. is the treasurer of the group. She is 35 and married.  She has a six year old son who has just started school. Shairgul’s husband works in construction and earns 5000 soms per month. Shairgul herself is engaged in cattle breeding. She also sells dairy products every day. She makes 3500 soms per month. She applied for the loan because she needs money to repair her house. In the future Shairgul wants to increase her cattle numbers.

Tursunai T., 33, is married. She has a son and a daughter, both of whom study at school. Tursunai works as a waitress. Her husband went to work in Russia. Tursunai also breeds cattle and sells them after fattening. With the loan she wants to purchase a calf for breeding.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a calf

loans.name: Francine

texts.en:
Francine is 32 years old and is married with four children. She is well-known as a self-employed businesswoman selling styles of clothes for men as well as for women. She has been in this business for about four years and the hours of her business are from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Francine needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. With this loan, she hopes that she will improve her business by adding modern styles which undoubtedly will increase her sales as well as her profits.

With the earned profits, Francine will keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loans.use: To add modern styles of clothes

loans.name: Hue

texts.en: Hue B. N. is 34 years old. She lives in Xom Huong village. She is married with two children. She has a disk store. She has had this job for 5 years. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2004. In the last cycle, she borrowed 6,758,000 VND and repaid this amount punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,066,000 VND to expand her store.

loans.use: to expand her store

loans.name: Dufatanye Group

texts.fr:
Theoneste N., née à bugesera  secteur Sake l’Est du pays, marié, il a 4 enfants, il a 40 ans, son ainé a 17  ans et son dernier enfant à 10 ans et  son niveau d’éducation est primaire. Il vit avec sa famille à sake Bugesera. Tous  ses enfants vont à l’école. Avec son épouse ils travaillent pour faire vivre et améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Il fait le commerce des habits pour détail et pour  la couture dans le centre commercial de Sake qui est un centre rural mais qui en voie de développement.

Il appartient dans un groupe solidaire appelé DUFATANYE,  qui est un groupe dont les membres sont  tous commerçants et ils se garantissent mutuellement, Theoneste et son groupe travaillent pour faire vivre leurs familles en améliorant leurs conditions de vie et en amenant leurs enfants à l’école. En fait, le groupe a contracté un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Banking pour acheter les articles de leur commerce et les revendre, une partie du profit est  réinvesti pour maintenir la stabilité financière du groupe et épargner afin de préparer pour un bon futur.
texts.en:
Theoneste N. was born in Bugesera, in the Sake district in the Eastern part of the country. He is 40 years old, married with four children of whom the eldest is 17 and the youngest 10 years old. His level of education is primary. He lives with his family in Sake Bugesera, and all his children attend school. He earns his living together with his wife and they seek to improve their family’s living conditions. He sells clothing retail and for tailoring in the commercial area of Sake, which is a developing rural centre. He belongs to a solidarity group named Dufatanye, whose members are all merchants and provide each other mutual guarantee. Theoneste and his group work to ensure their family’s subsistence, improve their living conditions, and provide schooling for their children. In fact, the group has obtained a loan from the Amasezerano Community Banking association, to buy items for resale in their commerce. Part of the profit is reinvested to ensure the group’s financial stability, and put into savings to prepare for a prosperous future.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing for retail sales and for tailoring

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en: Phuong T. N. is 39 years old. She is married with two children. She grows rice and also makes rice cake to sell. She has had this job for many years. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND). She has participated in SEDA since 2004. In the last cycle, she borrowed 6,758,000 VND and repaid this amount punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,066,000 VND to buy rice to make rice cake.

loans.use: to buy rice to make rice cake.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma L. is from the town of Banga. She is 43 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Gemma owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Like other mothers, she works hard to be able to send her children to school and dreams of them completing college.

Gemma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This will be the first loan taken out by Gemma from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Ancilla

texts.en:
Ancilla was born in 1970 and is married with four children between 5 and 12 years old.

Ancilla owns a small business selling various products such as juice, cooking oil and so on and has an experience of three years in her business. She employs one person from her community as a helper so that her business runs well. The hours of her daily activities are from 6 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day except Saturday.

Now, Ancilla is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business. With this loan she hopes to earn more profit to be used in her daily activities.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda P. is from the town of Banga. She is 43 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Nilda owns & operates an agricultural business, planting & harvesting corn for sale. She dreams for her family to have better living conditions. 

Nilda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Nilda is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. This will be the first loan taken out by Nilda from CEVI. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora L. is from the town of Banga. She is 31 years old. Leonora is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Leonora owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She hopes to have good health for her so she could keep up with the hard work required at maintaining their farm. She says she only wants the best for her family.

Leonora joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Leonora from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Constance

texts.en:
Constance is 54 years old and is married. She struggles in selling a variety of foodstuffs, mainly cassava flour, corn flour, rice, sugar, etc. This is her fifth successful year in this business and the hours of her business are from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Despite five years of experience in the business, Constance's capital is still too low to expand meaningfully, with the result that her profits are still too low. To end this, she is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.

Once given this loan, Constance will expand her business through purchasing additional foodstuffs to sell. With these additional foodstuffs, her sales as well as her profits will increase. Thus, she will also be able to improve the living style of her family.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Bavubuka Twekembe-Mukono Group

texts.en: 37-year-old K. Fred has been running a fishing and fish selling business in Bunankanda-Mukono for the last 15 years. With monthly profits of 200,000 shillings, he has been able to support his family with this business. All his 3 children are happy and in good schools and his stable marriage has also played a major part in the successful running of his business. He says his wife has always been there whenever he needed her help. Fred was inspired by a close friend to try his hand at this business and since then he has never looked back. His first business, charcoal selling, though still running, is now secondary to fishing. He makes a larger profit fishing so he has never regretted making fishing his primary business. With this loan, this long planning, reserved and enterprising gentleman wants to purchase more fish in bulk to resell and consequently earn more profits.

loans.use: The purchase of more fish to resell.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn S. is from the town of Banga. She is 60 years old. Merlyn is married and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Merlyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. She also helps her husband maintain their rice farm and selling their harvest.

Merlyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and farm supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Merlyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and farm supplies.

loans.name: Jyambere Group

texts.fr:
Germain U., née à bugesera  secteur Sake l’Est du pays, marié, il a 3 enfants, il a 33 ans, son ainé a 6  ans et son dernier enfant à 2 ans et  son niveau d’éducation est primaire. Il vit avec sa famille à sake Bugesera. Cinq de  ses enfants vont à l’école. Avec son épouse ils travaillent pour faire vivre et améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Il fait le commerce des habits pour détail, avec ce prêt il veut  acheter les chemises et pantalons  pour hommes et femme et pour enfants, il effectue ce commerce dans le centre commercial de Sake qui est un centre rural mais qui en voie de développement. Il a pu construire une maison dans laquelle il habite, lui et sa famille.
Il appartient dans un groupe solidaire appelé JYAMBERE,  qui est un groupe dont les membres sont  tous commerçants et ils se garantissent mutuellement, Jérémie et son groupe travaillent pour faire vivre leurs familles en améliorant leurs conditions de vie et en amenant leurs enfants à l’école. En fait, le groupe a contracté un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Banking pour acheter les articles de leur commerce et les revendre, une partie du profit est  réinvesti pour maintenir la stabilité financière du groupe et épargner afin de préparer pour un bon futur.
texts.en:
Germain U. was born in Bugesera, in the Sake district in the Eastern part of the country. He is 33 years old. His eldest child is 6 and the youngest 2 years old. His education level is primary. He lives with his family in Sake Bugesera, and five of his children attend school. He earns his living together with his wife and they seek to improve their family’s living conditions. He retails clothing, and with this loan intends to buy shirts and pants for men, women and children. His business is located in the commercial area of Sake, which is a developing rural centre. He was able to build a house where he lives together with his family. He belongs to a solidarity group named Jyambere, whose members are all merchants and provide each other with mutual guarantee. Jérémie and his group work to ensure their family’s subsistence, improve their living conditions, and provide schooling for their children. In fact, the group has obtained a loan from the Amasezerano Community Banking association, to buy items for resale in their commerce. Part of the profit is reinvested to ensure the group’s financial stability, and put into savings to prepare for a prosperous future.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy shirts and pants for men, women and children

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian N. is from the town of Banga. She is 34 years old. Vivian is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Vivian owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Vivian has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

Vivian joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vivian is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She also plans to purchase two piglets to raise. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and two piglets to raise.

loans.name: Arceli

texts.en:
Arceli T. is from the town of Banga. She is 48 years old. Arceli is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Arceli owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Arceli also hopes to have enough capital to venture into raising pigs. She says she has to work hard so she can support her children's education.

Arceli joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arceli is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers, and other farm inputs. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Arceli from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Florentina S. is from the town of Banga. She is 53 years old. Florentina is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Florentina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. When free of farming duties, Florentina spends time selling dried fish around her community. She says it helps in providing for their daily needs.

Florentina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florentina is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and additional dried fish to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Florentina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Kiira Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
S. Soprano exudes self confidence and self esteem at first glance. He has invariably believed in his worth from his early 20s. These traits have been winning trump cards for him in successfully operating his 15-year-old retail and charcoal sales businesses in Kyaliwajjala-Mukono. At 43 years, S. has a success story connected with him that can act as motivation for today’s youth. Most youth lack that self-initiative, which normally comes about as a result of low self-esteem. For this happy-go-lucky married father of 5, a strong belief in your own abilities is a big plus especially from the point of view of running and consolidating any business enterprise. 

S. surprisingly got inspiration from his wife. His wife impressed upon him to try his luck at brick laying. This was his first business and with savings from that, he embarked on his current businesses. In a week, his net profits add up to 105,000 shillings. With this loan, he is looking forward to restocking his retail shop with an array of purchased items such as sugar, bars of soap, salt, plastics, soft drinks and bread that he will at length resell.

loans.use: The purchase of bars of soap, salt, sugar, soft drinks and bread for resale.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: 45-year-old Emma L. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has an 8-year-old child. Emma raises and fattens hogs for sale and also uses her backyard for planting vegetables that she sells in her community. She also loves cooking so she decided to earn from what she loves doing: she used part of their house to display cooked food that her neighbors and passersby buy from her. Emma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell and will also buy ingredients for her cooking business. This loan will be her first from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell and also ingredients for her cooking business

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en: Emelyn J. is from the town of Banga. She is 33 years old and is married with three school-aged children. Emelyn owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale and also helps her husband plant and harvest corn on their farm. She sells their harvest to their town's market. Emelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and farm supplies. This loan will be her first from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and farm supplies

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen G., a 49-year-old married mother with five school-aged children, is from the town of Banga where she earns a living planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over three years.

Helen joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having successfully repaid her previous loan from CEVI, she is now requesting a new one, her sixth, of 15000 PHP to purchase fertilizers and seeds. Helen plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her enterprise and sustain her family's income.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Gaudence

texts.en:
Gaudence is 33 years old and she is still single. Gaudence is well known for her business selling cloth as shown in the photo. This is her fourth successful year in this business. The hours of her business are from 8 am to 7 pm every day.

Gaudence needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.  With this loan, Gaudence will expand her business by purchasing cloth. With this additional cloth, Gaudence's sales as well as profits will increase.  If successful, Gaudence will keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of raw cloth

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more used clothes to sell

loans.name: God Gee Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “God Gee” group from Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. They are small businesspeople who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, in order to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each member of the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Ramatu C., who is pictured on the left. Ramatu was born in Makeni 38 years ago. She is the wife of a businessman and the mother of four children. 

Ramatu sells slippers and flip-flops and has been managing this business for many years. Ramatu will use her share of this loan to buy dozens of slippers to sell through her business.

loans.use: To buy dozens of slippers

loans.name: Let's United Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “Let’s United” group. They are small-scale businesspeople in the northern city of Makeni. This will be their first loan from SMT/Kiva lenders.  With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit. Consequently, their living standards will improve. At least they will be able to provide three meals a day for their children, pay their schools fees, buy them clothes to wear, and pay their medical bills in case any of them fall sick. 

Mosia S. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group. Mosia was born in Bo, a city in southern Sierra Leone. But he now lives in Makeni together with his wife, who is a businesswoman, and two children who attend primary school. 

Mosia is a tailor and has been in this profession for five years. Mosia will use his share of the loan to buy working materials such as poplins, cloths, threads, etc.

loans.use: To buy working materials such as poplins, cloths, threads, etc.

loans.name: Bless United Women Group

texts.en:
Esther S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Bless United Women. She is 43 years old and is married with three children who range in age from 12 to 23 years. She also cares for one sibling. Esther was only able to attend school through 9th grade due to lack of financial support.

For 14 years, Esther has been selling dried fish in Gardnerville Market on Somalia Drive, Monrovia, Liberia.

Esther plans to use her 7,500 Liberian dollar portion of this 34,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more dried fish to sell. She describes herself as a serviceable woman.

Esther’s dream is to improve her business and build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Jenneh is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more dried fish to sell

loans.name: New London Ii Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “New London II” group. They are businesswomen who run small businesses in Makeni, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of 500,000 leones each to enable them to further expand their businesses, make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Adama T. (on the left). Adama was born in Makeni. She is approximately 35 years old. Adama is married to a farmer and the couple have five children – two in primary school, two in secondary school and one who is no longer attending school. Adama sells flip-flops. She has been running this business for many years now. With her share of this loan, Adama will buy dozens of flip-flops to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy dozens of flip-flops

loans.name: Plan Your Future Group

texts.en:
Cynthia A., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called “Plan Your Future”. She is 32 years old and is married with four children who range from 7 to 12 years old. Cynthia was only able to attend school through 9th grade due to lack of financial support.

For three years, Cynthia has been selling cosmetics in Logan Town Market on Bushrod Island, Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 7,500 Liberian dollar portion of this 35,500 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more cosmetics to sell. She describes herself as a serviceable woman.

Cynthia’s goal is to grow her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Ainagul

texts.en:
Ainagul A. is 47 years old and was born in the south of Kyrgyzstan in a large family; her father was an actor and her mother was a schoolteacher. Unfortunately, in 1964, when Ainagul was one year old, her parents died in a car accident and Ainagul grew up at her grandmother’s house, helping her in the household: she milked cows and pastured the cattle.

From her childhood, Ainagul was eager to study and, after graduating from secondary school, she intended to pursue her studies through higher education. However, when Ainagul was 23, she was given into marriage.

Ainagul and her husband moved to the capital, Bishkek, where she graduated from Bishkek Humanities University with a degree with honors. Ainagul and her husband returned to the south of the country where Ainagul got a job as a researcher at Osh State University. In 1996, Ainagul divorced her husband. Some years later, Ainagul, being a very whole-hearted and persistent woman, adopted two little girls, who are presently 8 and 11 years old.

In 2004, Ainagul and her daughters moved to Belovodskoe village near the capital. It was the beginning of a new life which led Ainagul to start up her business. With an investment of only 6,000 Kyrgyz Soms, Ainagul started to sell foodstuffs at a local market in 2006. After four years, she already owns her own little shop.  Recently, she also bought two milk cows and began cattle-breeding.

Ainagul will use this loan of 100,000 Kyrgyz Soms to further broaden the range of the food products in her shop and to buy one more cow. With the revenues, she plans to renovate her shop and to give a good education to her daughters. As for Ainagul, she intends to get a driving license this year.


About Bai-Tushum and Partners:
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable members of the population. Its Kiva borrowers benefit from a 5% discount on their interest rate if they pay back without delay.

Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, it contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To broaden the range of her food products and to buy another cow

loans.name: Fatu

texts.en: Meet 48-year-old Fatu K., a small-scale businesswoman in Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. Fatu sells locally dyed cloths (gara lappers), baby clothes, bowls, coolers, etc. She has been a businesswoman for 10 years now. With a loan of SLL 2,000,000, Fatu will be able to expand her business by buying the above-mentioned items at wholesale. Fatu’s husband is a businessman too and all three of her children are adults.

loans.use: To buy gara lapper making materials (inks, white cotton cloth, etc), baby clothes, bowls, coolers, etc.

loans.name: Ngoné

texts.fr:
Madame Ngoné F. est une femme mariée de 46 ans qui habite dans la localité de Yoff plus précisément dans le quartier de Dagoudane. Elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 12 et 23 ans.
Madame F. a choisi l’activité de commerce dans laquelle elle évolue  depuis plus de  15 ans par passion mais aussi l’influence de  son mari a beaucoup contribué à ce choix. Elle est en même  temps artiste et évolue  depuis  plus de 20 ans dans la troupe Mame Ndiaré de Yoff.
Madame F. est sociétaire  de la caisse de Yoff depuis avril 2009. Elle a déjà  remboursé 2 prêts antérieurs. Elle sollicite un crédit  de 300 000 frs prévu pour l’achat d’habits pour enfants et autres marchandises diverses destines à renforcer son commerce. 
Son objectif étant  de réaliser  des bénéfices  en vue de satisfaire ses besoins personnels et améliorer la situation sociale de sa famille, madame F. pense que ce crédit  lui sera d’un très grand apport.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ngoné F. is 46 years old and lives in the locality of Yoff, or more precisely in its Dagoudane borough. She is married with four children whose ages vary from 12 to 23 years. Mrs F. chose the commercial activity she embarked on 15 years ago by passion but also through her husband’s influence, which contributed significantly to her choice. For the past 20 years she has also been a performing artist in the Mame Ndiaré troup of Yoff. Mrs F. is a member of the Yoff branch (of UIMCEC) since April 2009, and has already reimbursed two previous loans. She is requesting a loan for 300,000 francs destined to buy children’s clothing and various other merchandise to bolster her business. Her objective being to generate revenue to satisfy her personal needs and improve her family’s social situation, Mrs. F. believes this credit loan will help her significantly.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build up her stock

loans.name: Francine

texts.en:
Francine is 35 years old and is married with two children: the first one is 6 years old and the last is 5 years old. Francine owns a business selling various styles of shoes while her husband works in the private sector. This family works hard for the purpose of getting all the basic needs of their family.

Francine employs one person from her community as a helper and the hours of her shop are from 7 in the morning to 6 in the evening, every day except Sunday. Francine is seasoned in her business because this is her 12th year of successful operation.

Now, Francine is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing more shoes to satisfy her customers. With this loan she will be able to sort out her family problems.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: United Women Group

texts.en:
Oretha D., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called “United Women”. She is 43 years old and is married with six children who range from 10 to 21 years old. She was only able to attend school through 6th grade due to poverty. 

For five years, Oretha has been selling crème, body lotion, grease, shampoo, gel, etc., in Red Light Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 9,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 39,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more crème, body lotion, grease, shampoo, gel, etc. She describes herself as a determined woman.

Oretha’s dream is to improve her business, build a house and continue to educate her children.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Kpana is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more crème, body lotion, grease, shampoo, gel, etc.

loans.name: Bien Fait Plus Group

texts.en:
Patrick N. N. is the chairman of this community bank called “Bien Fait Plus” which means “Well done” in English. It is composed of fifteen members united in solidarity to receive Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.

Patrick, 31, is married and became a micro-entrepreneur in 2006 with beginning capital of $100. Today, his telephone booth business has prospered thanks to his hard work, good management and determination.

Patrick is a trustworthy client of HOPE DRC, having twice received and correctly repaid loans. He will increase his stock of merchandise with this next loan by purchasing phone accessories and prepaid cards to resell at a profit.

Patrick’s business brings in $60 per week and is located to the South-west of Kinshasa. His dream is someday to open a large general store in his area.

loans.use: To increase his business stock by buying phone accessories and prepaid cards to sell

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Blessing Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called “Blessing”. She is 51 years old, is widowed, and has five children who range from 10 to 34 years old. She was only able to attend school through 8th grade due to poverty.

For ten years, Elizabeth has been selling rice, cooking oil, sugar, flour and pepper in Chicken Soup Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

Elizabeth plans to use her 25,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 65,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more bags of rice, cooking oil, sugar and flour. She describes herself as a determined woman.

Elizabeth’s dream is to improve her business, build a house, and continue to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, cooking oil, sugar and flour to sell

loans.name: Fad Plus Group

texts.en:
Lutala is the leader of this community bank named “FAD Plus”. It is composed of fourteen members united in solidarity to receive Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.

Lutala has been selling secondhand clothing since 2005. He started his business selling one bundle of clothes. Over the years, his business has prospered through determination and hard work, and he has been able to build a loyal customer base that has stabilized his business.
