With good management and savings, Lutala has been able to reinforce his working capital. He started with one bundle of secondhand clothing and is up to ten bundles today. He sells at the market in the southwestern area of Kinshasa and his business makes $90 per week.

Lutala has already obtained five loans from HOPE DRC and correctly repaid them. He will increase his stock of merchandise with his next loan by buying a bundle of secondhand clothing to resell the clothes at a profit.

Lutala is confident in his business and he is determined to someday be a secondhand clothing importer and provider for the market in DRC (The Democratic Republic of the Congo) in general and Kinshasa in particular.

Lutala is 55 years old, married, and has five children between the ages 13 and 25 of whom two attend school.

loans.use: To purchase another bundle of secondhand clothing in order to reinforce his working capital

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Tugolokoke Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Nineteen years is the time 40-year-old Eva N. has spent having an oversight role over her retail business in Kyetume-Mukono. With 70,000 shillings as weekly profits, Eva has shown that through hard work and determination, one can achieve a great deal. This business has been bringing her dividends since she began it. 

She initially was a farmer and after the idea of diversifying her business crossed her mind, she made a decision to start her retail shop. She also operates a pig husbandry and poultry business. These have contributed to her drive to make more profits. With this loan, she wants to purchase retail items, such as sugar and maize flour, in bulk for resale.

loans.use: The purchase in bulk of more retail items such as sugar and maize flour, amongst other things, for resale

loans.name: Marta Luz

texts.es:
Martha Luz Z. Valencia tiene 39 años y vive en el barrio Villa del Carmen, con su cónyuge y sus 3 hijos en las edades de 10 a 15 años,  Municipio de Soledad en el Departamento del Atlántico. Tiene una miscelánea donde vende de todo un poco así usted puede comprar desde un lápiz hasta productos de bisutería, perfumes y detalles en general. Su negocio es de origen familiar surgió por su necesidad de hacer un aporte importante al sostenimiento de su hogar y para  poder solventar las necesidades de la comunidad, allí vende todo tipo de mercancías, especialmente  útiles escolares y papelería en general,  aprovechando la vecindad de su negocio con una zona escolar.

Este es sus segundo crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, desde el primero notó un aumento en sus ventas y  también que le produjo un mayor margen de ganancias por las compras de contado que hizo con su crédito,  el que le   funcionó como un el capital de trabajo a bajo costo. Ahora con su credikiva va a surtir la miscelánea de lápices, plumeros, libretas, moños, blusas, pulseras, binchas, colonias, aretes y perfumes femeninos y masculinos.

Su sueño es que sus hijos terminen una carrera universitaria y que su negocio sea reconocido no solo en su barrio, sino en su localidad,  por eso justamente su mayor desafío es posicionarlo en el mercado, aprovechando que vive en un barrio donde la oferta de mercancía económica tiene una gran demanda y eso es justamente lo que ella comercializa desde su miscelánea.
texts.en:
Martha Luz Z. Valencia is 39 years old and lives in the Villa del Carmen neighborhood, within the Soledad Municipality in the Atlantic Department with her husband and her 3 children, between ages 10 and 15. She has a general store that sells a little bit of everything, from pencils to accessories, perfumes and other items. It's a family business that started because she needed to make important contributions toward supporting her household and also to fulfill her community's needs. While her shop sells all sorts of products, the most useful items are the school and general stationary supplies; taking advantage of the fact that her business is next to a school. This is her second credit with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. Since her first credit, she has noticed an increase in sales and also a wider profit gap from being able to make her stock purchases in cash with her credit. It worked like a low cost work capital. Now, with her Kiva credit, she is going to stock her shop with pencils, pens, notebooks, overalls, blouses, bracelets, earrings, perfume and cologne. Her dream is for her children to earn a University degree and for her business to be known not only in her neighborhood but in the entire area. As such, her greatest challenge is to make a name for her business in the sector, taking advantage of the fact that she lives in a neighborhood where the availability of inexpensive merchandise is in high demand and this is exactly what she is commercializing off of with her general store.

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To supply her general store with pencils, pens, notebooks, overalls, blouses, bracelets, cologne, earrings, and perfumes.

loans.name: Vagif

texts.en:
Vagif H. is a 57-year-old man who breeds sheep and cattle in the small village of Bilasuvar city. He is married and has three children. He has been engaged in this business for the last 15 years. 

He sells cattle to the local butchers and cafes. His monthly income is about 250 to 300 Azerbaijani New Manat. He plans to use his loan to buy a milk cow and several sheep.

loans.use: Purchase one milk cow and two sheep

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and bread at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. 

Victoria is 39 years old and married to a peasant. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a motorbike for the transportation of charcoal bags to her home for stock.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Samangul

texts.en:
Samangul M. is 33, is married, and has four children. She has bred sheep for the last five years. Her monthly income is 250-300 AZN and her main customers are local butchers and cafés.

Samangul would like to expand her business and purchase more sheep for her herd. This will allow her to increase her profit and improve the lives of her dearest children. She applied for 1,000 AZN.

loans.use: To purchase ten sheep for her herd

loans.name: Getrude

texts.en:
M. Getrude is as lively as they come. The 50-year-old has a sparky sense of humor that close friends say has endeared her to many of her consorts but more importantly, they point out, to her customers.

Being cordial and welcoming is a winning factor that many people operating a business often gloss over. Getrude says no matter how adverse the situation may be, whether in terms of personal moods or a person’s business going through a checkered career, it is always advisable to maintain that cordial, serene and friendly attitude, especially in dealing with new, old and prospective customers.

Getrude’s seventeen-year-old retail shop has, to a large extent, been a benefactor of the aforementioned factors. In a month, Getrude makes profits to the total of 300,000 shillings.

Getrude set forth in business after she got ideas from her husband. Her first business, poultry, also played a leading role in helping her to get established. She used savings from that business to buy many of her first retail items.

With this loan, this married mother of nine wants to restock her shop with purchased items such as sugar, salt, maize flour, rice and soap.

loans.use: The purchase of items such as sugar, salt, maize flour and rice

loans.name: Ilqar

texts.en:
Ilqar A. is a 47-year-old man who is engaged in farming and has been doing this for the last ten years. He is married and has four children.

Ilqar also is a tractor operator but his main income comes from his farming business. His monthly income is 200-300 AZN but this is too low for such a big family. He applied for 800 AZN and he will use this loan to improve the irrigation system of his garden and to purchase two calves.

loans.use: To improve the irrigation system of his garden and purchase two calves

loans.name: Elkhan

texts.en:
Elkhan R. is a 45-year-old farmer who raises seasonal fruits and vegetables and also raises cattle. He is married and has three children.

Elkhan’s monthly income is 200-300 AZN and he has eleven years of experience in this field. He sells fruits and vegetables in the local bazaar and uses his cows for milk and milk products.

Now Elkhan has applied for 1,000 AZN in order to purchase one milk cow and more seeds. He will use this cow to start selling milk to the local people.

loans.use: To purchase one milk cow and seeds

loans.name: Takhmina

texts.en:
Takhmina A. is a 24-year-old woman who is married and has one son. Together with her husband, she breeds cattle.

Takhmina sells cattle to the local butchers for a profitable price and her monthly profit is 150-250 AZN. She has seven years of experience in this field.

Cattle breeding is the only source of income for Takhmina’s family. She applied for a 1,000 AZN loan in order to purchase two calves.

loans.use: To purchase two calves

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah S. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local Sudanese alcohol (siko) at home and is requesting a loan to stock crates of beer to sell.

Sarah is 49 years old and is married to a retired police officer. She has seven children and three of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

loans.use: To stock crates of beer to sell

loans.name: La Ilusion Group

texts.es:
Este grupo solidario se llama La Ilusión. Esta ubicado en la comunidad de Tepexco, en el estado de Puebla, México. El grupo esta conformado por 5 integrantes que se conocen por ser vecinos. Este es su 1er. Préstamo con Fundación Realidad.
La integrante del grupo la señora Ivet V. S. tiene 28 años de edad estudio para técnico en computación, tiene 2 hijos, 1 hombre y 1 mujer, Benito tiene 4 años de edad y estudia el Kinder, Azul Isabel tiene 8 meses de edad. La señora Ivet se dedica a vender pantalones de mezclilla para dama y necesita su préstamo para comprar pantalones de mezclilla para dama, vive en unión libre con el señor Herminio Quien se dedica al trabajar en el campo recibiendo un salario mínimo por esta razón se vio en la necesidad de emprender este negocio, iniciándolo hace 3 años, cuando el hermano de su compadre le dio la mercancía para comenzar a vender y le fue pagando poco a poco, su negocio esta en su casa en Tepexco, atiende de 5 a 15 clientes por dia, regularmente son las jovencitas que acuden a su negocio a comprar sus pantalones y la señora Ivet siempre es amable y cordial como siempre las atiende personalmente para que regresen a comprar su mercancía. Su negocio es importante para ella por que le ayuda en su economía, tiene ingresos para la alimentación de su familia, también puede atender a sus pequeños hijos. Sus sueños y esperanzas son seguir trabajando para obtener mas ganancias para darles a sus hijos una mejor vida, ampliar su negocio aumentando en playeras y ropa interior para dama, invitar a más personas para obtener mas prestamos. Los desafíos que enfrenta el negocio son los costos elevados, a veces hay pérdidas porque los pantalones salen mal o defectuosos, tambien tiene mucha competencia pues varias personas venden los mismos productos que ella vende. 
Tepexco es un lugar con clima caluroso hay cerros una presa, algunos campesinos tienes animales como caballos y burros que usan para trabajar o para trasladarse a sus trabajos y a sus casas.  
Los integrantes del grupo son Ivet V. S. va a comprar con su préstamo pantalones para dama por mayoreo para surtir su negocio. La señora Maria del Rosario Gutiérrez C. va a comprar abono por bulto para su cultivo de sorgo y venta. La señora Delia T. M. va a comprar ropa. Pantalón para dama, caballero y niño, faldas, blusas, ropa interior camisetas etc. para surtir su negocio. Ana Maria C. M. va a compra alimento para cerdo y lechones para crianza, también va a comprar tomates, jitomates, chiles seco, queso etc. para preparar sus alimentos (antojitos Mexicanos). La señora Irene B. R. va a compra la inscripción y catálogos para iniciar la venta de sus productos compra de kit es un paquete nutricional para su club nutricional.
La señora Ivet quiere decir a Kiva y a Fundición Realidad: “ojala que sigan ampliando los prestamos porque así nos ayudan a levantar los negocios, gracias por apoyarnos”
texts.en:
This group is called La Ilusión. They are located in the Tepexco community in the state of Puebla, Mexico. The group is composed of 5 members that know each other as neighbors. This is their first loan with Fundación Realidad. One of the group members is Señora Ivet V. S., who is 28 years old and is studying to become a computer technician. She has 2 children, 1 boy and 1 girl. Benito is 4 years old and is in Kindergarten while Azul Isabel is 8 months old. Señora Ivet works selling women denim trousers and needs a loan to purchase more. She lives with her partner, Señor Herminio, who works in the fields and is paid minimum wage. As such, she saw a need to begin this business, starting it over 3 years ago, when her friend's brother gave her some merchandise to begin selling and paid her little by little. She operates her business out of her house in Tepexco and attends 5 to 15 clients a day. Normally, they are young women that visit her business and Señora Ivet is always nice, cordial, and attends to them personally so that they return for more. Her business is important because it adds to her household's income. It provides towards her family's groceries and also allows her to care for her children. Her dream is to continue to work to increase her earnings in order to be able to provide her children with a better life, expand her business by eventually selling women's bathing suits and underwear, and invite more people to join the group to obtain more loans. The challenges that she faces are her business' high bills. Sometimes there are losses due to trousers coming out badly or defected. Also, there is a lot of competition because various people sell the same products as she does. Tepexco is a very hot place with hills. Some of the people have animals, like horses and donkeys that they use to work or to get to their jobs or their houses. The members of the group are: Señora Ivet V. S., who, with her loan, is going to purchase women trousers at wholesale with which to stock her business. Señora Maria del Rosario Gutiérrez C. is going to purchase fertilizer in bulk for her sorghum cultivation and to resell. Señora Delia T. M. is going to purchase clothing, such as trousers for women, men, and children, skirts, blouses, underwear, shirts, etc, with which to stock her business. Señora Ana Maria C. M. is going to purchase food for her pigs and baby pigs. She is also going to purchase tomatoes, dried chiles, cheese, etc. in order to prepare her antojitos Mexicanos (typical Mexican snacks). Señora Irene B. R. is going to pay for the initial fee and the catalogs to start selling nutritional packets for her nutrition club. Señora Ivet would like to say the following to Kiva and Fundación Realidad: "I hope that you continue to increase your loans because they help us uplift our businesses. Thank you for supporting us!"

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase women's trousers.

loans.name: Sibomana

texts.en:
Sibomana is 35 years old and married with five children.  Sibomana is a driver of a motorbike and he has been in this business for about 10 years.  The business hours are from 6 am to 9 pm every day.

Sibomana needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Sibomana will purchase one more motorbike and this motorbike will hopefully allow him to increase his revenue.  If successful, Sibomana will improve the living style of his family and he will also renovate his own house.

loans.use: To purchase one additional motorbike

loans.name: Vuqar

texts.en:
Vuqar S. is a 39-year-old man who has been breeding sheep for the last 12 years. He is married and has four children. 

Vuqar sells sheep in the livestock bazaar and to the local butchers. His monthly income is 250 Azerbaijani New Manat (AZN). He would like to increase his profit and improve the life of his family. For this purpose, he applied for a loan of 1000 AZN and will use it to purchase six sheep and one calf.

loans.use: Purchase six sheep and one calf

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel M. T. is twenty-six years old, single, and does not have any children yet. His business is located at Barsheba estate in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites--not forgetting the Indian Ocean's white beaches. 

He has been selling fruits and vegetables for the last year to the local people. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy more fruits and vegetables to expand his business. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future and even open other outlets. He describes himself as very customer friendly.

loans.use: Expanding store inventory

loans.name: Chajerina

texts.en: Chajerina J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Chajerina is 41 years old and married; her husband is a peasant. She has three children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Alphonsine

texts.en:
Alphonsine is 29 years old and married with one child who is one and a half years old. Alphonsine's husband is a driver. This family works hard to develop their family. Alphonsine owns a small business selling shoes. This business is profitable in the city where her business is located.

Alphonsine is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing more shoes to sell. This loan will be fruitful because she will be able to sell a large quantity of shoes, which will allow her to earn more profit.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Phoibe

texts.en:
Phoibe is 36 years old and married with three children. The oldest child is 14 years old, the next is 11 years and the last one is 8 years old. Phoibe’s husband works in government. They both work hard in order to provide their children all the necessary things. Phoibe, in particular, has five years of experience in her business but she has only a little capital, which is a challenge for her. The hours of her shop are from 7 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day except on Saturday.

Phoibe is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business. With the extra money that Phoibe expects to earn, she will be reinvesting in her business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Donatha

texts.en:
Donatha is 39 years old and married with two children. The oldest one is 16 years old and the youngest one is 2 and half years old. Donatha owns a small business selling various styles of shoes. This business is profitable. That is why she chose it. Donatha’s husband works in the bank. This family has a target of obtaining all things that they need. Donatha’s business is open from 7 in the morning to 6 in the evening every day except on Saturday.

Donatha is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business. With this expansion, she will be able to earn more profit, which is the target of everyone in business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 21 years old and married with two children. The first one is 5 years and the last one is 2 years old. Christine is a businesswoman as is her husband. This family works hard in order to get everything the family needs. Christine has a business selling the various styles of the shoes. Christine has 10 years of experience working from 6 in the morning to 5 in the evening every day except on Saturday.

Christine is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business. With this expansion, she will be able to earn more profit, which is the target of everyone in the business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es:
Actualmente, Oscar vive en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo donde la mayoría de sus vecinos y amigos se dedican al turismo.  Hace muchos años atrás vivía en la ciudad de Urubamba donde tenía una ferretería y tuvo que cerrar porque había mucha competencia y no había muchos clientes. 

Decidido a empezar una nueva vida, Oscar se mudo a Ollantaytambo, donde tenía algunos amigos y familiares lejanos quienes le motivaron para abrir una tienda. Utilizó el dinero de la liquidación  de la ferretería para abrir una nueva tienda en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo, donde vende pintura, cemento, clavos, chapas, lijas y muchas cosas más. Hace diez años que se dedica al negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su negocio y con los beneficios que obtiene saca adelante a sus tres hijos. 

Oscar en un padre responsable y trabajador que desprende una imagen de experiencia y profesionalidad. Un flujo regular de clientes visita su tienda pero por los meses de marzo las ventas estaban bajas debido a las lluvias que cayeron en la ciudad. Oscar pertenece al banco comunal “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” y es uno de los fundadores, con su próximo préstamo, Oscar espera recibir $300 y le gustaría implementar su ferretería y desea comprar focos ahorradores, clavos y accesorios eléctricos. El sueño de Oscar es abrir otra ferretería en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo.
texts.en:
Oscar currently lives in the city of Ollantaytambo, where most of his neighbors and friends work in the field of tourism. Many years ago, he lived in the city of Urubamba, where he had a hardware store. He had to close it because there was a lot of competition and he did not have many customers. Determined to start a new life, Oscar moved to Ollantaytambo, where he had some friends and distant family members who encouraged him to open a store. He used the money from the liquidation of his hardware store to open a new store in the city of Ollantaytambo, where he sells paint, cement, nails, metal sheets, sandpaper, and much more. He has operated this business for ten years, and it is going very well for him, thanks to the dedication he puts into the business. With the benefits he obtains from his work, he has helped his three children get ahead. Oscar is a responsible and hard-working father who presents an image of experience and professionalism. A regular flow of customers visits his store, but his sales are low in the month of March, due to the rains that fall in the city. Oscar belongs to the communal bank called “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” ["The Friendship of Ollantaytambo"], and he is one of the founders. With his next loan, Oscar hopes to receive $300, and he would like to improve his hardware store. He wants to buy energy-saving lightbulbs, nails and electrical accessories. Oscar's dream is to open another hardware store in the city of Ollantaytambo.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying energy-saving lightbulbs, nails and electrical accessories

loans.name: Norma Patricia

texts.es:
Norma Patricia E. A. tiene 36 años.  Es soltera y vive con los hijos,  vive en Ventanas provincia de Los Ríos. Tiene 2 hijos, Alejandro y Estefanía.

Norma es una socia de la ventanilla rural la “Y”, que está ubicada a hora y media de Ventanas. Son 17 socios en total, que en la mayoridad se dedican a la agricultura. Esto es el primer préstamo que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa San José.

Norma  se dedica al comercio, vende ropa y calzado en un local de su vivienda. Realiza sus compras cada mes en la ciudad de Guayaquil y Quito y los vende en su casa o de puerta en puerta.

Solicita el préstamo para la compra de ropa y calzado para incrementar el negocio. Piensa que el crédito es una oportunidad para salir adelante. Sus sueños es comprar una casa para aumentar el negocio. Enfrenta desafíos es la competencia de la localidad. 
Le gusta viajar y algún día le gustaría salir del país.
texts.en:
Norma Patricia E. A. is 36 years old and a single mother of 2 children, Alejandro and Estefania. They live in Ventanas, in the province of Los Rois. Norma is a member of a communal bank located an hour and a half from Ventanas. There are 17 members in total, the majority of them working in agriculture. This is the first loan that they will be taking with Cooperativa San Jose.

Norma works selling clothing and shoes from a shop in her house. She purchases her inventory every month in the city of Guayaquil and Quito, and she sells her merchandise from her house or door to door. She is requesting this loan to purchase more clothing and shoes to grow her busines. She feels this loan is a chance to improve the quality of her life. Her dream is to be able to purchase her own home from where she can grow her business. She faces challenges from the competition in her area. Norma would like to be able to travel, and one day leave Ecuador.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase more clothing and shoes to grow her small business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Mahira

texts.en: Mahira H., 50, is a widow with three sons. She engages in several activities: she breeds cattle and poultry, and raises corn, sunflowers, and other seasonal fruits and vegetables.  Her monthly profit is 200-250 Azerbaijani manat (AZN). She would like to expand her cattle business as it is very profitable and in high demand. She applied for a loan of 900 AZN to purchase sheep. As she is the only financial source in her family, Mahira works very hard to cover the needs of her dearest sons, who actively help her.

loans.use: purchase eight sheep and fodder

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 36 years old and married with two children: the first one is 5 years old and the last one is 3 years old. Rose runs a business as does her husband. Rose sells clothes in Kigali city. Rose is seasoned in her business with 10 years of experience. The hours of her shop are from 8 in the morning to 7 in the evening, every day except on Saturday.

Rose is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to purchase various styles of clothes. With this loan, Rose will be able to satisfy her customers.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Betrice

texts.en: Betrice D. is currently in the business of selling various drugs at the medical clinic and is requesting a loan to stock more drugs to sell.  Betrice is 32 years old, married, and her husband is a director. She has three children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build wards for admitting patients.

loans.use: Stock more drugs to sell

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
Francisca es cusqueña y actualmente vive en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo que se encuentra ubicado a 1 hora y 20 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco. Las vendedoras actuales del mercado “Virgen de Asunta de Ollantaytambo” vendían sus productos de forma ambulatoria porque no habia mercado y no tenían puestos de venta. 

Actualmente cada vendedora cuenta con sus propios puestos de venta y Francisca también. Francisca en el puesto de venta vende comestibles y también se dedica  a la venta de artesanía y pertenece a la asociación de artesanos “Señor de Choque Quilca”. La pueden encontrar en su puesto cada tres veces a la semana desde las 8am hasta las 11am. 

Francisca desprende  una imagen de responsabilidad y amabilidad. Un flujo de turistas visitan el mercado y el negocio se anima bastante por las mañanas a la llega de los turistas que se dirigen a visitar las ciudadela inca de Machu Picchu. Ella vende artesanía de calidad como por ejemplo mantas, chulos, sombreros  y bordados. Hace 15 años que se dedica a la venta de artesanía y le va muy excelente.
  
Con su próximo préstamo, Francisca espera recibir $ 300 UDS. Por el momento, su tienda esta modestamente equipado con mercadería necesaria. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo  en comprar mercadería como por ejemplo gaseosas, arroz, azúcar, muchos productos más. 

Francisca pertenece al banco comunal “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo”, y es una de las fundadoras. Hace 4 años atrás un grupo de vecinas se juntaron para formar el banco comunal y vieron en la Asociación Arariwa una alternativa de ayuda con los préstamos.
texts.en:
Francisca is from Cusco, but now lives in the city of Ollantaytambo which is located about one hour and 20 minutes from the city of Cusco. The vendors of the market "Virgin of Ollantaytambo" used to sell their merchandise door to door and around the city, since there was no market nor any stalls from which they could operate. Today, each vendor counts on his own stand, Francisca as well. From her stand, Francisca sells food, snacks and grocery items. She also sells handicrafts from the group of artists called "Senor de Choue Quilca". You will find Francisca at her stand 3 times a week from 8 in the morning until 11 in the morning.

Francisco exudes the qualities of a responsible and friendly person. A constant flow of tourists visit the market and the environment is very animated in the mornings when the tourists headed for Machu Picchu arrive. Francisca sells quality handicrafts, for example table cloths, hats and embroidery. She has been selling handicrafts for 15 years now and the business has gone well. With her next loan, Francisco will receive $300US. For the moment, her stand is modestly stocked with the merchandise she needs. She would like to use the money from this loan to puchase sodas, rice, sugar and other products.

Francisco is a member of the communal bank "La Amistad de Ollantaytambo", or "The Friendship of Ollantaytambo" and she is one of the founders. 4 years ago a group of neighbors got together to form the communal bank and saw in the Association Arariwa an alternative way to get help with the loans.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase products for her small business such as sodas, rice, sugar and other ingredients she uses to prepare the snacks she sells

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 50 years old and married with eight children who are between the ages of 8 and 24 years old. Beatrice makes a living by selling pastries in her shop and some drinks. She has been in this small business for about two years. The hours of her business are from 6 am to 9 pm every day.

After realizing that her sales can't satisfy her customers, Beatrice decided to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. With this loan, Beatrice will hopefully satisfy her customers by purchasing a large quantity of beverages and pastries. If successful, Beatrice will hopefully earn more profit which will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loans.use: To buy a large enough quantity of beverages and pastries

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.es:
Aurelia tiene 55 años y tiene 5 hijos, ella vive en la comunidad D. Pachar que se encuentra ubicado a 10 minutos D. Urubamba. La socia tiene un pequeño negocio el cual consiste en compra y venta D. frutas para lo cual a un inicio se le hacía difícil ya que no contaban con mucho capital, fue entonces que se presento la oportunidad D. pertenecer al banco comunal D. la Asociación Arariwa el cual le brindo apoyo con préstamos D. dinero y así pudo mejorar su negocio.  La pueden encontrar en su puesto D. venta  en el mercado central “Virgen Asunta D. Ollantaytambo”, donD. venD. frutas traídas del valle D. la Convención y del norte del país, los 7 días D. la semana, desD. las 8 D. la mañana hasta las 4 D. la tarD.. 

Aurelia es una mujer responsable y trabajadora. Un flujo regular D. clientes visita su puesto y el negocio se anima bastante por las mañanas. Con su próximo crédito, Aurelia espera recibir $100. Por el momento, su puesto esta modestamente equipado D. frutas. Le gustaría usar el dinero D. este préstamo en comprar más frutas como por ejemplo plátanos, piñas, naranjas, etc. 
      
Aurelia pertenece al banco comunal “la Amistad D. Ollantaytambo” D. la Asociación Arariwa.
texts.en:
Aurelia is 55 years old and has got 5 children. She lives in the Pachar community, which is located 10 minutes from Urubamba. She has got a small business, which consists in the purchase and sale of fruits. Its beginnings were difficult because she didn't have much capital. It was then that she was presented with the opportunity to join the communal bank, Asociación Arariwa, which offers loans and from there was able to improver her business. She can be found at a stall in the central market, "Virgen Asunta D. Ollantaytambo", where she sells fruit brought from the Convención valley and from the north of the country, seven days a week, from 8am until 4pm. Aurelia is a responsible and hard working woman. A regular flow of customers visit her stand, and her business gets quite busy in the mornings. Aurelia hopes to receive $100 in her next loan. At the moment, her stand is moderately stocked with fruit and she would like to use the money from her next loan to purchase more fruit, such as bananas, pineapples, oranges, etc. Aurelia pertains to the communal bank, Amistad D. Ollantaytambo of Asociación Arariwa.

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase more fruit, such as bananas, pineapples, oranges, etc.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia M.  is currently in the business of selling saddles, clothes and women's handbags at the market and is requesting a loan to stock women's headdresses and some pairs of shoes to sell.  

Lucia is 53 years old and married. She has seven children and three of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend her business by building another shop for a supermarket business.

loans.use: Stock women's headdresses and some pairs of shoes to sell

loans.name: Lucila

texts.es:
Lucila nació en Ollantaytambo y vive en el barrio de San Isidro de la misma ciudad. Lucila lleva toda la vida rodeada de la ganadería y la agricultura. La mayoría de los pobladores de Ollantaytambo hoy en día ven en el turismo una forma de darse una mejor calidad de vida. 

Lucila en su domicilio a cómodos unos dormitorios para ofrecer servicios de hospedaje a los turistas nacionales y extranjeros que llegan a la ciudad de Ollantaytambo, cada habitación cuesta aproximadamente entre 15 y 20 soles. Ella en la plaza principal de la ciudad de Ollantaytambo tiene una casa y lo alquila para un cafetín. Lucila desde muy joven aprendió la cosecha y siembra. La socia tiene una pequeña chacra, al lado de su casa, donde cultiva maíz, papas, cebollas, etc. Hace varios atrás falleció su esposo y se quedo con sus cinco hijos. Lucila desprende una imagen de una señora muy tierna y amable. 

Con su próximo préstamo de $150 USD. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo para comprar semillas y abono. Lucila pertenece al banco comunal “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” y es una de las socias fundadoras.
texts.en:
Lucila was born in Ollantaytambo and lives in the neighborhood of San Isidro. She has lived her entire life surrounded by cattle raising and agriculture. The majority of the residents in Ollantaytambo today see tourism as a way to help improve their quality of life. In her home, Lucila rents out a couple of rooms to both Peruvian as well as foreign tourists. Each room costs approximately 15 - 20 soles. Her home is located in the main plaza of Ollantaytambo. From the time she was young Lucila learned how to harvest and plant. She has a small plot of land, alongside her house, where she grows corn, potatoes and onions. Several years ago her husband died and left Lucila with 5 children to support. She exudes the qualities of a kind and friendly woman. With her loan of approximately $150US, Lucila would like to buy seeds and fertilizer. She is one of the founding members of the communal bank called "La Amistad de Ollantaytambo", or "The Friendship of of Ollantaytambo".

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Gulsare

texts.en: Gulsare Q. is 48 years old, married, has four children and has made a living raising cattle for the last nine years. She breeds cattle to produce both meat and milk, and earns 200-250 AZN a month from her work. She has applied for a loan for 1,000 AZN to buy a new cow and a calf to raise.

loans.use: to buy a cow and a calf to raise

loans.name: Anita

texts.es:
Anita lleva toda la vida rodeada del turismo. Sus vecinas y ella ven en el turismo una forma de negocio rentable. En la ciudad de de Ollantaytambo se encuentra una de las ruinas más importantes del Incanato y también es paradero obligatorio para los turistas que se dirigen a ciudadela Inca de Machu Picchu. Desde los 19 años, Anita se las ingenio para vender artesanía en la ciudad, actualmente vende en dos sitios, el primero es en la estación de trenes y el segundo en la plaza de principal de Ollantaytambo. La pueden encontrar en sus puestos de venta que está equipado con mercadería surtida como por ejemplo mantas, chompas, mochilas, bordados, sombreros, maletines desde las 8 am hasta 4pm, los 7 días de la semana. 

Anita desprende  una imagen de alegría y amabilidad. Un flujo de regular de turistas nacionales y extranjeros que visitan su puesto. Ella vende sus productos de calidad y de un buen acabado. 

Con su próximo crédito, Anita espera recibir $500 USD. Por el momento, su puesto está bien equipado de mercadería porque en  esta época del año hay una alta vista de turistas. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo para comprar una computadora personal para el estudio de sus hijos. Anita pertenece hace 7 años al banco comunal “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo”.
texts.en:
Anita has been surrounded by tourism her entire life. She and her neighbors recognize that tourism offers an opportunity for profitable business. One of the most notable Incan ruins is located in the town of Ollantaytambo. This is also the location of a mandatory stopping point for tourists who are on their way to the Incan city of Machu Picchu. Since age 19, Anita has sold artisan crafts in the city. She currently works at two different sites, one being located at the train station and the other in the main plaza of Ollantaytambo. Anita can be found at either of her locations from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., 7 days a week. Anita sells assorted merchandise such as blankets, sweaters, bags, embroidered goods, hats and small cases. She maintains an attitude of joy and kindness. Tourists, both domestic and foreign, regularly visit her locations for the high-quality products. Anita hopes to receive $500 for her next loan. Because this time of year is a season of increased tourism, her operation is currently well-stocked with merchandise. She would like to use the money from this loan to buy a personal computer, which will aid her children in their studies. Anita has been a member of the communal bank "La Amistad de Ollantaytambo" for seven years.

Translated from Spanish by Tyson Shelley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a personal computer to aid her children's studies.

loans.name: Romania

texts.es:
Romania nació y vive en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo donde la mayoría de los pobladores se dedican a al turismo. La ciudad de Ollantaytambo se encuentra ubicada a hora y media de la ciudad del Cusco por la carretera asfaltada. Romania abrió hace cuatro años atrás un restaurante “Doña Romania” en su domicilio y está ubicado en la calle principal o entrada a la ciudad de Ollantaytambo. La pueden encontrar en su restaurante, los 7 días de la semana, desde las 7 de la mañana hasta bastante tarde en la noche, o hasta que se agote la comida. 

Romania desprende una imagen de responsabilidad y amabilidad. Un flujo de clientes visita su restaurante y el negocio se anima durante la hora del desayuno, almuerzo y cena. Ella también vende pollos a la brasa y sirve porciones abundantes de papas fritas, una porción de pollo a la brasa, ensalada y cremas. 

Con su próximo préstamo, Romania espera recibir $1000 USD.  Por el momento, su restaurante está bien equipado con las necesidades básicas. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo para uso personal, ella desea terminar de construir su casa y va comprar tejas, etc. 

Romania es una persona responsable, puntual y pertenece al banco comunal “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo”  y hace 6 años que participa en banco comunal pues es una de las socia fundadoras. Las reuniones del banco comunal se hacen cada treinta días en la oficina central de la Asociación Arariwa sede Ollantaytambo.
texts.en:
Romania was born in and currently lives in the city of Ollantaytambo where the majority of its inhabitants work in tourism. The city of Ollantaytambo is located an hour and a half from the city of Cusco by asphalt road. Four years ago, Romania opened a restaurant called “Doña Romania” in her home, which is located on the main street or entrance to the city of Ollantaytambo. She can be found in her restaurant 7 days a week from 7 in the morning until pretty late in the evening, or until the food runs out. Romania is the very image of responsibility and kindness. A constant flow of customers visits her restaurant and business picks up at breakfasttime, lunchtime and dinnertime. She also sells grilled chicken and serves heaping portions of french fries, slices of chicken, salad and custard. With her next loan, Romania hopes to receive $1,000 USD. At the moment, her restaurant is well equipped with the basic necessities. She would like to use the money from this loan for personal use. She wants to finish building her house and purchase tiles et cetera. Romania is a responsible and punctual person and belongs to the communal bank "La Amistad de Ollantaytambo" (Friendship of Ollantaytambo). She has belonged to it for six years and is one of its founding members. Communal bank meetings occur every thirty days in the central office of the Arariwa Association headquarters in Ollantaytambo.

Translated from Spanish by David Cannon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build her house and to buy tiles et cetera

loans.name: Doris

texts.es:
Doris nació y vive en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo.  La mayoría de pobladores que viven en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo se dedican al turismo y otros pobladores que viven alrededor se dedican a la agricultura y ganadería. Doris  hace 15 años atrás abrió un pequeño hospedaje “La Casa de Doris”, en su domicilio, donde hospeda a turistas nacionales y extranjeros. Ella y su esposo Américo tienen un hijo. Doris en su hospedaje tiene cuartos matrimoniales, simple y dobles, donde los precios oscilan entre 20 soles o 50 soles dependiendo el cuarto. Le pueden encontrar en su hospedaje, que está equipado de computadoras personales  para acceder a internet, cocina, sala de espera, baños privados, etc. todos los días de la semana, las 24 horas del día.  Doris desprende una imagen de amabilidad y alegría. Un flujo regular de turistas se hospeda durante los meses de mayo, junio, julio y agosto. 

Con  su próximo préstamo, Doris espera recibir $200 USD. Por el momento, su hospedaje esta modestamente equipado con las necesidades más básicas. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo para ampliar el hospedaje y desea comprar ventanas y puertas para la parte que están construyendo.
texts.en:
Doris was born in the city of Ollantaytambo and still lives there. Most of the people of Ollantaytambo work in the field of tourism, while others who live outside the city work in farming and ranching. Fifteen years ago, Doris opened a small inn, “La Casa de Doris” ["Doris's House"] in her home, where she hosts foreign and domestic tourists. She and her husband Américo have one child. In her inn, Doris has single, double and family rooms, with prices ranging from 20 to 50 soles depending on the room. Every day of the week, 24 hours a day, she can be found in her inn, which is equipped with personal computers for Internet access, a kitchen, a waiting room, private bathrooms, etc. Doris projects an image of friendliness and cheerfulness. A steady flow of tourists stays at the inn during the months of May, June, July and August. With her next loan, Doris hopes to receive $200 in US dollars. For the moment, her inn is modestly equipped with the most basic needs. She would like to use the funds to help expand her inn, buying windows and doors for the new part that is under construction.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying windows and doors

loans.name: Leocadie

texts.en:
Leocadie is 27 years old and married with three children who are 2, 4 and 5 years old. Leocadie struggles by in life selling a variety of jewelry. She has been in this business for about seven years. The hours of her business are from 6 am to 9 pm every day.

Leocadie needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a. This loan will allow her to expand her business by adding the sale of modern jewelry. With this additional jewelry, Leocadie will hopefully earn more profit which will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability of the business as well as her family.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods, mainly jewelry, etc.

loans.name: Rosa Mercedes

texts.es:
Rosa Mercedes nació y vive en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo.  La mayoría de pobladores que viven en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo se dedican al turismo y los pobladores que viven alrededor se dedican a la agricultura y ganadería. 

Rosa desde muy niña aprendió de sus padres a sembrar, cultivar, ordeñar y pastear animales. Rosa tiene al lado de su domicilio una pequeña chacra donde siembra maíz, pasto, etc. Ya son 15 años que esta con el negocio y le va muy bien, ella vende sus productos en el mercado de Virgen Asunta de Ollantaytambo pues tiene un puesto de venta. Con su próximo préstamo, Rosa que espera recibir de $200. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo en comprar abono. 

Rosa es una mujer emprendedora, responsable y puntual y por ese motivo sus amigas la invitaron a participar D. banco comunal “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” de la Asociación Arariwa.
texts.en:
Rosa Mercedes was born in Ollantaytambo and still lives there. Most people who live in the city of Ollantaytambo work in the field of tourism, while those who live outside the city work in farming and ranching. Since she was a very small girl, Rosa learned from her parents how to plant and cultivate crops and how to milk cows and take them to pasture. Next to her home, Rosa has a small farm where she grows corn, hay, etc. She has operated this business for 15 years, and it is going very well for her. She sells her products at the Virgen Asunta market in Ollantaytambo, where she has a sales stall. With her next loan, Rosa hopes to receive $200. She would like to use the funds from this loan to buy fertilizer. Rosa is an enterprising, responsible and punctual woman, and for this reason, her friends invited her to participate in the communal bank “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” ["The Friendship of Ollantaytambo"], of the Arariwa Association.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fertilizer

loans.name: La Joya Group

texts.es:
ElL. son el grupo La Joya, llamados así por la colonia donD. radican. Este es su primer ciclo con nosotros y están muy contentos D. formar parte D. Fundación Realidad. La Joya la conforman: 
*María Félix G. M. (venta D. cosméticos por catalogo)
*Antonia C. M.  (venta D. servilletas)
*Maribel Zacarías S. (venta D. cosméticos por catalogo)
*Noe Jiménez Hernández (venta D. F.)
*María del Carmen Copelia Rodríguez B. (venta D. dulces)
*Alma Yasmin M. Rodríguez (venta D. dulces)
*Francisca M. A. (venta D. dulces)
*Dulce Paola J. Sánchez (venta D. productos D. limpieza)
*Magdalena G. G. (venta D. servilletas)
*María D. Lourdes García V. (Papelería)REPRESENTANTE DEL GRUPO
*María Carmen S. E. (venta D. productos nutricionales)
*Margarita M. D. L. S. (venta D. dulces)
*Rebeca F. P. (venta D. adornos) y 
*Fausto Epigmento F. (venta D. dulces) 
 
Noe Jiménez D. 32 años D. edad es casado y con dos hijas en edad escolar. El era empleado D. una florería pero con el tiempo el sueldo que le brindaban ya no le alcanzaba ya que L. gastos D. sus hijas iban incrementando así que se decidió independizarse, hace un año que Noé junto con su esposa decidieron comenzar con la venta D. F., durante la semana su esposa se ubica en L. tianguis mientras Noé va D. casa en casa, así es como se dan a conocer, el surte cada tercer día, va hasta L. invernaderos para encontrar buenos precios y a su regreso tiene que tomar un taxi para no maltratar su mercancía ya que traerL. en transporte publico es algo complicado, también elabora floreros y diferentes adornos que le solicitan sus clientes, con el crédito solicitado el va a comprar F., chalupas, bases para L. arregL. ya que así podrá tener un mayor ingreso para L. gastos D. familia y poder construir un cuarto mas en su casa para tener un buen espacio para sus hijas. Sus planes son poner un pequeño local en su domicilio para poder exhibir sus arregL. y así aclientarse un poco mas al igual que  desea que sus hijas puedan terminar una C. y salgan adelante 
 
ElL. están muy contentos con el crédito recibido por que así podrán incrementar su mercancía y tendrán un mayor ingreso para poder cubrir L. gastos D. sus familias.
texts.en:
This is the “La Joya” (The Jewell) group. They chose this name because it’s also the name of their neighborhood. They are in their first cycle with us and are very happy to be a part of Fundación Realidad. The group’s members and activities are: *María Félix G. M. (cosmetic sales via catalog) *Antonia C. M. (serviette sales) *Maribel Zacarías S. (cosmetic sales via catalog) *Noe Jiménez Hernández (flower sales) *María del Carmen Copelia Rodríguez B. (sweets sales) *Alma Yasmin M. Rodríguez (sweets sales) *Francisca M. A. (sweets sales) *Dulce Paola J. Sánchez (cleaning product sales) *Magdalena G. G. (serviette sales) *María D. Lourdes García V. (paper goods) – GROUP’S REPRESENTATIVE *María Carmen S. E. (nutrition items sales) *Margarita M. D. L. S. (sweets sales) *Rebeca F. P. (decoration sales) *Fausto Epigmento F. (sweets sales) Noe Jiménez is 32 years old, married, and has two school aged daughters. He used to work for a florist, but eventually his salary was no longer enough, since his daughters’ expenses continued to increase. A year ago he decided to go out on his own and he and his wife began selling flowers. During the week his wife sets up a stall, while Noe goes door to door. This is how they have become known. Every third day he visits the growers in order to buy at good prices, and takes a taxi home so as not to damage his merchandise. Trying to bring it back via public transportation gets complicated. He also makes vases and different decorations at his customers’ request. He will use the money from this loan to buy flowers, chalupas (in this case, dishes used for flower arrangements – not food), and foam bases for his arrangements. This will allow him to increase his income so he can cover his family expenses. It will also allow him to add a room to his house so that his daughters will have more room.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Flowers and supplies for making arrangements

loans.name: Grisel

texts.es:
Grisel nació y vive en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo.  La mayoría de pobladores que viven en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo se dedican al turismo y otros pobladores que viven alrededor se dedican a la agricultura y ganadería. Grisel hace varios años atrás abrió un puesto de venta de artesanía, en la plaza de principal de Ollantaytambo, donde vende artesanía como por ejemplo chompas de lana, sombreros, bordarnos, ponchos, etc. Ella y su esposo Fredy tienen un hijo. Le pueden encontrar en su puesto de venta, que está equipado con regular mercadería, los 7 días de la semana, desde las 8 de la mañana hasta bastante tarde en la noche. Grisel desprende una imagen de amabilidad y alegría. Un flujo regular de turistas vistan su puesto de venta y el negocio se anima durante los meses de mayo, junio, julio y agosto. 

Con  su próximo préstamo, Grisel espera recibir $300 USD. Por el momento, su puesto esta modestamente equipado con las necesidades más básicas. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo para en comprar más mercadería como por ejemplo sombreros, chompas, ponchos.
          
Grisel es una mujer emprendedora, responsable y puntual y por ese motivo sus amigas la invitaron a participar del banco comunal “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” de la Asociación Arariwa.
texts.en:
Grisel was born and lives within the city of Ollantaytambo. Most of Ollantaytambo’s inhabitants work in the tourist industry and those living in the surrounding area work in agriculture; farming and raising livestock. Several years ago Grisel opened a store to sell arts and crafts in the city’s main plaza, where she sells things such as wool sweaters, hats, embroidery, ponchos, etc. She and her husband Fredy have one son. One can find her at her store, which is stocked with regular merchandise, seven days a week from 8:00 am until well into the night. Grisel presents an air of friendship and happiness. A regular flow of tourists visit her store and the store is lively during the months of May, June, July, and August. Grisel is hoping to receive a $300 loan. For the time being her store is modestly stocked with the basic necessities, but she would like to use the money from this loan to buy more merchandise, such as hats, sweaters, and ponchos. She is a very entrepreneurial, responsible, and punctual woman, so her friends invited her to participate in the “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” (Friend of Ollantaytambo) communal bank of the “Asociación Arariwa.”

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Merchandise for resale

loans.name: Fabiana

texts.es:
Fabiana nació y vive en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo.  La mayoría de pobladores que viven en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo se dedican al turismo y otros pobladores que viven alrededor se dedican a la agricultura y ganadería. Fabiana hace tres años atrás abrió un tienda de abarrotes, en la avenida principal de la ciudad Ollantaytambo, donde vende comestibles como por ejemplo arroz, azúcar, fideos, aceite, leche, gaseosas, etc. Ella y su esposo Fredy son casados y fruto de este matrimonio tienen tres hijos. Le pueden encontrar en su tienda, que está equipado con regular mercadería, los 7 días de la semana, desde las 5 de la mañana hasta bastante tarde en la noche. Fabiana desprende una imagen de amabilidad y alegría. Un flujo regular de clientes vistan su tienda y el negocio se anima durante todos los días. 

Con  su próximo préstamo, Fabiana espera recibir $1000 USD. Por el momento, su puesto esta modestamente equipado mercadería con los productos básicos. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo para en comprar más mercadería como por ejemplo arroz, fideos, conversar de atún, etc.
           
Fabiana es una mujer emprendedora, responsable y puntual y por ese motivo sus amigas la invitaron a participar del banco comunal “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” de la Asociación Arariwa.
texts.en:
Fabiana was born and lives within the city of Ollantaytambo. Most of Ollantaytambo’s inhabitants work in the tourist industry and those living in the surrounding area work in agriculture; farming and raising livestock. Three years ago Fabiana opened a grocery store along the city’s main street, where she sells food such as rice, sugar, noodles, cooking oil, milk, soft drinks, etc. She is married to Fredy and they are blessed with three children. One can find her at her store, which is stocked with regular merchandise, seven days a week from 5:00 am until well into the night. Fabiana presents an air of friendship and happiness. She has a regular flow of customers who visit her store and it motivates her every day. Fabiana is hoping to receive a $1,000 loan. For the time being the store is modestly stocked with the basic items, but she would like to use the money from this loan to buy more merchandise, such as rice, noodles, tuna, etc. She is a very entrepreneurial, responsible, and punctual woman, so her friends invited her to participate in the “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” (Friend of Ollantaytambo) communal bank of the “Asociación Arariwa.”

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Dulia

texts.es:
Dulía nació y vive en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo.  La mayoría de pobladores que viven en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo se dedican al turismo y otros pobladores que viven alrededor se dedican a la agricultura y ganadería. Dulía tiene 35 años y hace tres diez atrás abrió un bar restaurante, en la ciudad Ollantaytambo, donde vende cerveza y comidas especiales como por ejemplo chicharon, adobo, etc. Ella es casada y fruto de este matrimonio tiene dos hijos. Le pueden encontrar en su bar que está equipado con regular productos, los 7 días de la semana, desde las diez de la mañana hasta bastante tarde en la noche. Dulia desprende una imagen de amabilidad y alegría. Un flujo regular de clientes vistan su bar y el negocio se anima durante todos los fines de semana y por las noches. 

Con  su próximo préstamo, Dulía espera recibir $700 USD. Por el momento, su puesto esta modestamente equipado con poca mercadería.  Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo para en comprar más cervezas.
           
Dulia es una mujer emprendedora, responsable y puntual y por ese motivo sus amigas la invitaron a participar D. banco comunal “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” de la Asociación Arariwa.
texts.en:
Dulía was born in the city of Ollantaytambo. Most of Ollantaytambo’s inhabitants work in the tourist industry and those living in the surrounding area work in agriculture; farming and raising livestock. Dulía is 35 years old. She opened a restaurant-bar in town thirty days ago, where she sells beer and specialty dishes, such as pork rinds, adobo, etc. She is married and has two children. One can find her in her bar, which is stocked with regular products, seven days a week, from 10:00 am until very late at night. Dulía exhibits an air of happiness and friendship. A regular flow of customers visits her bar and business is lively in the evenings and on the weekends. Dulía hopes to receive a loan of $700. At this time her bar is not very well stocked and she wants to use the money to buy more beers. Dulía is a very entrepreneurial, responsible, and punctual woman, so her friends invited her to participate in the “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” (Friend of Ollantaytambo) communal bank of the “Asociación Arariwa.”

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Beer to stock her pub

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more soap and slippers to sell to his customers

loans.name: Flor Andina Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal “Flor Andina” actualmente se encuentra en el I ciclo y está conformado por personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos. Las reuniones del banco comunal son cada treinta días en la oficina central D. la Asociación Arariwa. 

Las actividades económicas D. los algunos D. los socios a las que se dedican son por ejemplo, venta D. productos D. belleza, venta D. frutas, venta D. perfumes, venta D. comida y venta D. relojes. Otros socios brindan servicios D. viajes turísticos, alquiler D. carros y empleada D. una ONG. 

Justina, tiene 62 años, es viuda y tiene seis hijos (2 mujeres y 4 varones), ella nació y vive en la ciudad del Cusco. Hace varios años que abrió un pequeño restaurante en su domicilio donD. sirve almuerzo. Hace varios atrás su esposo falleció, y Justina se quedo sola al cuidado D. sus hijos. 

Decidida a continuar su vida, Justina se dedico D. completo al negocio. Utilizo sus ahorros para implementar el restaurante, donD. aproximadamente atienD. a más 20 D. clientes todos los días. Le pueden encontrar en su restaurante, que está equipado con sillas y mesas, D. lunes a sábados, desD. las 9 D. la mañana hasta bastante tarD., o hasta que se agote la comida y los domingos venD. platos especiales extras como por ejemplo chicharon y caldo D. cabeza. 

Con su próximo préstamo, Justina  espera recibir S/. 500 soles. Por el momento, su restaurante esta modestamente equipado con las necesidades más básicas. Le gustaría emplear el dinero  D. este préstamo en comprar más gaseosas, arroz y azúcar.
texts.en:
The “Flor Andina” (Andean Flower) communal bank is currently in its first loan cycle and is maD. up of hard-working, enterprising people who constantly seek opportunities to get ahead and, with their daily efforts, to give their children a better future. The communal bank's meetings are held every 30 days at Asociación Arariwa's central office. Some of the members' economic activities are, for example, sales of beauty products, fruit sales, perfume sales, food sales and watch sales. Other members offer their services as tour guides, renting cars, and a member is employed by a non-governmental organization (NGO). Justina is 62 years old. She is a widow and has six children (two women and four men). She was born and lives in the city of Cusco. Several years ago, Justina opened a small restaurant in her house, where she serves lunch. Several years ago, her husband passed away, and Justina was left to take care of her children alone. Deciding to continue with her life, Justina dedicated herself completely to her business. She used her savings to start the restaurant, where she attends to approximately 20 customers everyday. They can find her in her restaurant, which is equipped with chairs and tables, Monday through Saturday from 9 in the morning until quite late, or until the food runs out. On Sundays she also sells special dishes like, for example, chicharrón [fried pork rinds] and caldo D. cabeza [sheep's head soup]. With her next loan, Justina hopes to receive 500 new soles. For the moment, her restaurant is modestly equipped with the most basic necessities. She would like to use the money from this loan to buy more sodas, rice and sugar.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase soda, rice and sugar

loans.name: Erika Lourdes

texts.es:
Erika Lourdes A. E. tiene 20 años.  Es soltera y vive con los padres,  en Ventanas provincia de Los Ríos. No tiene  hijos. 

Erika es una socia de la ventanilla rural la “Y”, que está ubicada a hora y media de Ventanas. Son 17 socios en total, que en la mayoridad se dedican a la agricultura. Esto es el primer préstamo que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa San José.

Erika  se dedica al comercio, vende cosméticos en Yambal. Realiza sus compras por medio de revistas y vende  de puerta a puerta.

Solicita el préstamo para invertir en el negocio y ponerse otro. Piensa que el crédito es una oportunidad para salir adelante. Sus sueños es tener su propio negocio y vivir con sus padres. Enfrenta desafíos es la competencia de la localidad. 

Le gusta hacer deporte y estudiar.
texts.en:
Erika Lourdes A. E. is 20 years old. She is single and lives with her parents in Ventanas, in in Los Ríos province. She has no children. Erika is a member of the “Y” communal bank, located an hour and a half from Ventanas. It has a total of 17 members, most of whom work in agriculture. This is their first loan through the San José Cooperative. Erika works in the retail trade, selling Yanbal cosmetics. She makes her purchases through catalogs and sells her merchandise from door to door. She is requesting the loan to invest in her business and start another one. She believes that the loan will provide an opportunity for her to get ahead. Her dreams are to have her own business and keep living with her parents. One of the challenges she faces is the competition in the area. She likes to play sports and study.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investing in her business and starting another one

loans.name: Carlos Hernan

texts.es:
Carlos Hernan V. V., tiene 26 años.  Es soltero y vive con los padres,  vive en Ventanas provincia de Los Ríos. No tiene hijos. 

Carlos es un socio de la ventanilla rural la “Y”, que está ubicada a hora y media de Ventanas. Son 17 socios en total, que en la mayoridad se dedican a la agricultura. Esto es el primer préstamo que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa San José.

Carlos se dedica a la ganadería, cría vacas. Realiza sus compras cada semana en Echeandia y vende las vacas en Ventanas.

Solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de más ganado. Piensa que el crédito es una oportunidad para salir adelante. Sus sueños es tener dinero para comprar un vehiculo para transportar el ganado. Enfrenta desafíos es la falta de dinero.

Le gusta jugar fútbol.
texts.en:
Carlos Hernan V. V. is 26 years old. He is single and lives with his parents in Ventanas, province of Los Ríos. He does not have children. Carlos is a member of the "Y" solidarity group, which is located an hour and a half from Ventanas. There are 17 members altogether, who mainly work in agriculture. This is the first loan they have taken out with Cooperativa San José. Carlos raises cows. He makes his purchases every week in Echeandia and sells the cows in Ventanas. He is asking for the loan to invest in buying more cattle. He thinks the loan is an opportunity to get ahead. His dream is to have money to buy a vehicle for transporting the cattle. A challenge he faces is lack of money. He likes to play soccer.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle purchases

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cartons of soap to sell to her customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying construction materials

loans.name: Maria Piedad

texts.es:
Maria Piedad I. C., tiene 57 años.  Es casada y vive con el esposo y los hijos,  en Ventanas provincia de Los Ríos. Tiene 3  hijos. 

Maria es una socia de la ventanilla rural la “Y”, que está ubicada a hora y media de Ventanas. Son 17 socios en total, que en la mayoridad se dedican a la agricultura. Esto es el primer préstamo que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa San José.

Maria  se dedica al comercio, a la venta de pollos pelados. Realiza sus compras cada semana en Echeandia y vende en la misma localidad.

Solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de pollos. Piensa que el crédito es una oportunidad para salir adelante. Sus sueños es tener dinero para comprar un terreno para tener pollos y otros animales. Enfrenta desafíos es la falta de dinero.

Le gusta leer y caminar en el campo.
texts.en:
Maria Piedad I. C. is 57 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and children in Ventanas, in Los Ríos province. She has 3 children. Maria is a member of the “Y” rural solidarity group, located an hour and a half from Ventanas. It has a total of 17 members, most of whom work in agriculture. This is their first loan through the San José Cooperative. Maria is in the retail trade, selling plucked chickens. She makes her purchases each week in Echeandia and sells her products in the same area. She is requesting the loan to invest the funds in buying chickens. She believes that the loan is an opportunity for her to get ahead. Her dream is to have enough money to buy a plot of land to raise chickens and other animals. One of the challenges she faces is the lack of money. She enjoys reading and taking walks in the country.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying chickens

loans.name: Sumac Puririsun Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal “Sumac Puririsun” actualmente se encuentra en el III ciclo y está conformado por personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos. Las reuniones del banco comunal son cada treinta días en la oficina central D. la Asociación Arariwa. 

Las actividades económicas D. los algunos D. los socios a las que se dedican son por ejemplo, venta D. comida, venta D. cuyes y gallinas, venta D. artesanía, venta D. pasto, venta D. rocoto relleno y venta D. tamales. Otros socios brindan servicios D. cuidado D. niños y obrero. 

Neil, tiene 24 años y tiene un hijo, ella nació en el distrito Cusipata que esta y ubicado a 45 minutos D. la ciudad del Cusco y actualmente vive en la ciudad del Cusco. Neil desD. los 11 años está rodeada del negocio D. venta D. tamales. Su cuñada Nayda se dedicaba a la preparación D. tamales y Neil le ayudaba a su cuñada a vender los tamales en los buses que se dirigían D. la ciudad D. Sicuani a la ciudad del Cusco. Ella subía a los carros y se suplicaba a los choferes para que ella pueda ofrecer sus tamales. Hace varios años atrás se caso y tuvo que venirse a vivir a la ciudad del Cusco para esta al lado D. su esposo. 

Decidida a empezar una nueva vida, se mudo al Cusco. Utilizo sus ahorros para preparar y vender los tamales en el terminal terrestre D. buses D. la ciudad del Cusco, donD. ella sube a los buses y ofrece a los viajeros. La pueden encontrar en el terminal, los 7 días D. la semana, desD. las 5 D. la mañana  hasta las 6 D. la tarD. o hasta que se agote los tamales, Ella  venD. tamales D. dos sabores D. sal y D. azúcar a un costo D. 0.50 soles cada tamal.

Con su próximo préstamo, Neil espera recibir S/. 1000 soles. Le gustaría comprar maíz, hoja D. planta D. maíz, azúcar, huevos, pasas y muchos insumos más. Por ahora, Neyl está preocupada porque el director del terminal le quiere desalojar y le está obligando a alquilar un puesto D. venta pero ella no cuenta con suficiente dinero para alquilar.  El sueño D. la socia es abrir una pequeña tienda D. venta D. comestibles en su domicilio y desea convertirse en una microempresaria.
texts.en:
The “Sumac Puririsun” communal bank is currently in its third loan cycle. It is maD. up of hard-working and enterprising people who are always looking for opportunities to get ahead and to give their children a better future through their daily efforts. The communal bank's meetings are held every 30 days at the central office of the Arariwa Association. The economic activities of some of the members are, for example, selling food, selling hens and guinea pigs, selling handicrafts, selling hay, selling stuffed peppers, and selling tamales. Other members proviD. services such as child care and manual labor. Neil is 24 years old and has one child. She was born in Cusipata district, located 45 minutes from the city of Cusco, and she currently lives in the city of Cusco. Since she was 11 years old, Neil has been surrounded by the business of selling tamales. Her sister-in-law Nayda went into the business of preparing tamales, and Neil helped her sell the tamales in the buses that travel from the city of Sicuani to Cusco. She got into the buses and asked the drivers if she could offer her tamales to the passengers. Several years ago, she got married and had to come live in the city of Cusco to be with her husband. Determined to start a new life, she moved to Cusco. She used her savings to prepare tamales and sell them at the bus station in Cusco, where she gets on the buses and offers them to the travelers. She can be found at the terminal 7 days a week, from 5 in the morning until 6 in the evening, or until the tamales run out. She sells tamales in two varieties, sweet and savory, at a price of 0.50 soles each. For her next loan, Neil hopes to receive 1000 Peruvian soles. She would like to buy corn, corn husks, sugar, eggs, raisins and many more ingredients. At present, Neil is worried because the director of the bus terminal wants to evict her; he is requiring her to rent a sales stand, but she does not have enough money to rent one. Her dream is to open a small food store in her home, and she would like to become a microentrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying corn, corn husks, sugar, eggs, raisins and many more supplies

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann R. lives in the town of Surallah. She is 29 years old, married and has three very young children. Mary Ann makes a living as a farmer, growing mainly rice. She has been in this business for more than three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from her work.

Mary Ann joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid five  previous loan  from CEVI and is applying for a new one, for 15,000 PHP to buy fertilizer for her crop. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training which are provided at regular group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Deidamia Marilin

texts.es:
Deidamia Marilin R. J., tiene 23 años.  Es casada y vive con el esposo y los hijos,  en Ventanas provincia de Los Ríos. Tiene 2 hijos, Nataly (5) y Paul (1). 

Deidamia es una socia de la ventanilla rural la “Y”, que está ubicada a hora y media de Ventanas. Son 17 socios en total, que en la mayoridad se dedican a la agricultura. Esto es el primer préstamo que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa San José.

Deidamia  se dedica a la agricultura, siembra naranja. Realiza sus compras cada semana donde el señor Gerardo y vende la misma localidad.

Solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de naranja y cacao desea sembrar a futuro. Piensa que el crédito es una oportunidad para salir adelante. Sus sueños es tener un negocio propio e incrementar los ingresos. Enfrenta desafíos es la falta de dinero.

Le gusta el comercio y salir a vender las naranjas.
texts.en:
Deidamia Marilin R. J. is 23, married, and lives with her spouse and children in the Ventanas province in Los Rios. She has two children, Nataly (5 years) and Paul (1 year). Deidamia is a member of the rural community bank, the “Y”, which is located an hour and a half from Ventanas. There are 17 members in total, the majority of whom work in agriculture. This is the first loan they have taken out with the San Jose Cooperative. Deidamia works in agriculture, planting oranges. She makes her purchases every week in Mr. Gerardo’s location and sells in the same place. She requests the loan to invest in the purchase of oranges and cocoa that she wishes to plant in the future. She thinks the loan is an opportunity to get ahead in life. Her dreams are to have her own business and to increase her income. The challenge she faces is a lack of capital. She enjoys business and going to sell the oranges.

Translated from Spanish by Rachael Mossey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in the purchase of oranges and cocoa that she wishes to plant in the future

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is 50 years old and  married with six children between the ages of 9 and 20. Flora makes a living by selling drinks made from sorghum. This is her tenth successful year in the business. Her business hours are from 6 am to 9 pm every day.

Flora needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a. With this loan, Flora will purchase a large quantity of sorghum to make into drinks. With the use of this loan, Flora will also start wholesaling to retailers who operate the same business. If successful, Flora will hopefully earn a lot of money and this income will allow her to keep reinvesting in her business and start saving for a better future for her family.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of sorghum to make into drinks for sale

loans.name: Divina

texts.en:
Divina D. lives in the town of Surallah. She is 38 years old, married and has seven school-aged children. She makes a living as a farmer, growing mainly rice, and has been in this line of work for more than 19 years. 

Divina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid five previous loans from CEVI, and is applying for a new one, for 15,000 PHP, to buy seeds, fertilizer and other items for her farm. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to improve her family's living standards. 

About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI provides not only credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training at regular group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer and other items for her farm

loans.name: Mbukam

texts.en:
Born in 1982, Mbukam M. is married and a mother of two children. She has been very hardworking since she joined GHAPE as she explained how good it is for a woman to work for herself and care of the children. Her desire is to work for her children’s education and pay for their apprenticeship. Also, she says she finds it very difficult to take care of her two children because for some months back she has been having some marital problems. Because of that, her husband has not been giving her food money for the family. With these difficulties, she looked for a place to get capital in order to do some buy and sell trade, which would give her income. With the inability to get investment capital, which could give her higher income to meet her children’s needs and the family, she decided to join GHAPE in 2009, and since then she has successfully received and repaid one loan.
