loans.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samuel O. N. is thirty-five years old, married and has four children aged between ten and two years old. His wife helps him in running the business and they hope to grow the business and create employment for people.

His business is located at Mikindani estate in Mombasa and it is well known by the name Liera Tailoring. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian Ocean's white beaches.

Samuel makes clothes for men and women of all ages. He also makes school uniforms, something he has engaged in for the last ten years.  He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is that he has limited space for his business and the area is also very dusty and this makes clothes dirty and spoils the sewing machine.

This is the reason as to why Samuel is taking a 30,000 KES loan to purchase a new machine and relocate to a new premise.  He hopes to expand his business and employ people whom he will be directing. He describes himself as social.

loans.use: Buy a new sewing machine and pay rent deposit on new premises.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en: Remedios T. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 47 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. She is a fish vendor. Her husband goes fishing and she sells all his catch in the market and around her community. She hopes to be able to acquire pigs that she could raise. Remedios joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly in recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but, additionally, savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets

loans.name: Restituta

texts.en: Restituta J. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 47 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Restituta owns and operates a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish to the market. Restituta has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities. Restituta joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Restituta has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Restituta is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly in recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but, additionally, savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets

loans.name: Simon Kipngetuny

texts.en:
Simon Kipngetuny C. is a man of 57 years. He is married to Salina and they are blessed with four beautiful children. Simon and his wife are both farmers who live in the Mafuta area in the outskirts of Eldoret. He plants maize and wheat for resale after harvest and has been in this business for 10 years now. He gets a yearly income of 150,000 Kenyan shillings.

With this loan, Simon plans to buy fertilizer for his farm, and with the interest he is going to get, he plans to expand his farming business. In the future, he plans to feed, clothe and provide for his family and expand his farming business by renting more plots for planting maize and wheat.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Rizalina

texts.en: Rizalina B. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 34 years old. Rizalina is single and has a 1-year-old child. To make a living, Rizalina runs a bakery. The main source of income for the business comes from baking and selling bread in the local community. Rizalina has been engaged in her business for over six years. Rizalina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rizalina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Rizalina is requesting a new loan of 20,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase additional cooking ingredients, like sugar and flour. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Rizalina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional cooking ingredients, like sugar and flour

loans.name: Elisha Kiprotich

texts.en:
Elisha Kiprotich N. is a 28-year-old man. He is married to Teresa and they are blessed with two children who are aged 4 and 2 years. They live in the Mafuta area in the outskirts of Eldoret. Elisha is a farmer who plants maize and wheat for resale after harvest. Elisha has been farming for five years now and gets a yearly income of 120,000 Kenyan shillings.

This will be Elisha's third loan with KADET and he plans to use the entire loan to buy fertilizer for his farm. With the income he is going to get from the sale of the produce, he plans to pay school fees for his children.

In the future, he plans to educate his children to the highest level and also expand his business to large-scale farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for the farm

loans.name: Nhoi Duoi1-3 Group

texts.en:
To T. H. is 46 years old and lives in Nhoi Duoi village with her husband and her son. She has a store and sells everything for everybody in her village. She has had this job for many years. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND).

She has participated in SEDA since 2009. For her last loan, she borrowed 2,375,000 VND and has completely and punctually repaid this amount. For this loan, she would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND to expand her store.

About the other borrowers in her group:
Thuy T. D. is 36 years old. She would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND in order to breed poultry.

Hong T. D. is 31 years old. She would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND in order to invest in her store.

loans.use: to expand her store

loans.name: Nhoi Duoi 1-2 Group

texts.en:
Ngai T. N. is 40 years old and lives in Nhoi Duoi village, Co Loa commune. She is married with three children who are going to school. She is a worker. She has an aluminum window store and her husband works there. They have a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND.

This is the first time that Mrs. Ngai has participated in SEDA and she would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND in order to expand her store. She is the leader of a 6-member group loan from SEDA.
 
About other borrowers in her group:
Vy T. D. is 37 years old.  She would like to borrow 6,758,000 VND to invest in her store.
Xuan T. T. L. is 23 years old.  She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND in order to breed pigs.
Be T. D. is 26 years old.  She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to breed poultry.
Lan T. C. is 44 years old.  She wants to borrow 5,450,000 VND to breed pigs.
Thoa T. N. is 28 years old.  She sells vegetables in the market and  wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND for her small business.

loans.use: in order to expand her store

loans.name: Anabelle

texts.en: Anabelle C. is from the town of Trento. She is 31 years old. Anabelle is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Anabelle raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Anabelle has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Anabelle joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anabelle has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Anabelle is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This will be the second loan taken out by Anabelle from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance, and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Biasha

texts.en:
Biasha is married to a businessman with two children: one attends school and the other one is too young for school. She rents a house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Biasha has been operating her business of selling kikois (pieces of colored cloth used as clothing) for the last seven years by going from door to door, women being her potential customers. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase a bale of kikois.

Biasha hopes to build rental houses in future. She decided to work with Yehu so as to get financial support and improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase a bale of kikois

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en: Cristina R. is from the town of Trento. She is 53 years old. Cristina is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Cristina raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also manages a sari-sari (variety) store, where she sells basic food and daily-need products. Cristina has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Cristina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cristina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Cristina is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and additional store inventory. This will be the second loan taken out by Cristina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance, and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and additional store inventory

loans.name: Sahadatou

texts.fr: M. Sahadatou est née le 13 Octobre 1961 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Depuis près de quarante ans, Sahadatou vit au quartier Kpondéhou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Sahadatou est mariée à SADIKOU Salami et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple subvient ensemble aux besoins de la famille. Il y a environs trente ans que Sahadatou vend des draps, des rideaux et des foulards à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l'aidant à faire face à ses différentes charges. Sahadatou achète ses produits à Lomé au Togo, et aussi au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin. C'est la deuxième fois que Sahadatou sollicite un concours financier auprès de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux faire face à la demande de plus en plus grandissante de sa clientèle.Sahadatou a bien remboursé son premier crédit.
texts.en:
Sahadatou M. was born 13 October 1961 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. For the past 40 years, Sahadatou lived in the Kpondéhou borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Salami Sadikou and is the mother of three children, all attending (or having attended) school. The couple share the handling of family expenses. Some thirty years ago Sahadatou began the retail sales of sheets, drapes and scarves in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. This revenue-generating activity helped her meet her financial responsibilities. She gets her products from Lomé in Togo and also from Nigeria, a country neighbouring Benin. This is the second time Sahadatou is requesting financial support from ALIDé, seeking to strengthen her activity and respond to the ever-increasing demands of her customers. Sahadatou has fully reimbursed her first loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sheets, drapes, scarves, etc.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn P. is from the town of Trento. She is 37 years old. Evelyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Evelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be the second loan taken out by Evelyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance, and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Amatour Ramath

texts.fr: S. Amatour Ramath est née le 14 Mai 1985 et vit depuis trois ans au quartier Sègbèya à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Ramath a fréquenté l'école jusqu'à l'université. Ramath n'es pas encore mariée et n'a pas encore d'enfants. Ramath vit seule et assure seule ses différentes charges. Pour faire face à ses charges, Ramath vend des voiles, des chapeaux de mariage, et de façon secondaire, des tenues françaises à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Ramath achète ses articles au Nigéria et à Lomé au Togo, Etats voisins du Bénin. Ramath exerce cette activité depuis trois ans et a obtenu une fois de prêt à ALIDé, prêt qu'elle a bien remboursé. Ramath  désire développer davantage son activité et mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Ramath sollicite un deuxième crédit.
texts.en:
Amatour Ramath S. was born on May 14, 1985 and has been living for the last three years in the Sègbèya district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has finished high school. She is not yet married and has no children. She lives alone and supports herself. In order to meet her expenses, Ramath sells headscarves, bridal hats, and, as a secondary activity, French-style clothing in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Ramath stocks up in Nigeria and in Lome in Togo, the countries neighboring Benin. She has been in this business for three years; she already had a loan from ALIDé before and duly repaid it. Ramath would like to expand her business and better meet customer demand, which is why she is seeking a second loan.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing headscarves, bridal hats and outfits

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma P. is from the town of Trento. She is 36 years old. Gemma is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Gemma owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also grows hogs for fattening and sale. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Gemma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and livestock feeds. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Gemma from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure and livestock feeds

loans.name: Teo

texts.en:
Teo is a widow with five children. Three of her children go to school, the others work at small jobs.  She own's a pub in Nalukolongo, selling all types of beer, local brew and gin.  She buys crates of beer from delivery vans and kegs of local brew from Ndeeba. Teo uses public transport to and from Ndeeba.  

Teo is going to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and kegs of local brew and gin.   She has done this business for six years and has been with MCDT for five years.  Besides this bar business she also owns a restaurant. She sells beer on a retail basis and she works seven days a week.  Her main challenge is that there are many bars around her area of operation. Teo aspires to see her business grow and start selling on wholesale basis only.  She decided to join MCDT because it was giving loans to women who live at the grass roots level.  She resides in and owns her house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her greatest  monthly expense in a month is food and school for her three children.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and kegs of local brew

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda T. is from the town of Trento. She is 56 years old. Gilda is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Gilda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Gilda has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Gilda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gilda has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Gilda is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Gilda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda T. is from the town of Trento. She is 34 years old. Linda is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Linda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Linda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years. She wishes to be a successful businesswoman and also dreams for her children to finish college.

Linda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Linda has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Linda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Linda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is married to an electricia. They have two children and also take care of her younger sister. Harriet sells soft dinks to earn a living and works in a semi-urban city of Kawempe. She buys passion fruits and oranges from Owino market and uses public transport to and from shopping.  Harriet goes shopping once a week.   She will use this loan to buy more bags of passion fruits, sugar and oranges.  Harriet has been in this business for eleven years.  Besides this soft drink business she also owns a video library and sells from her home.  She works seven days a week and her main challenge is that during rainy season she does not sell as much because the demand is low.

Harriet wants to make more profits from her business to be able to look after her family.  She joined MCDT because  they provide her with timely loans. She resides in and rents a two roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water.   Her monthly expenses include food, school fees and food .

loans.use: To buy bags of passion fruits, sugar and oranges

loans.name: Rafiatou

texts.fr: R. Rafiatou est née le 08 Septembre 1980 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Rafiatou est mariée à AKILOCHO Idrissou, et est mère d'un enfant qui est scolarisé. Rafiatou vit depuis sept ans au quartier Adogléta à Cotonou, avec son enfant. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et aux besoins de son enfant, Rafiatou vend des tenues pour enfants, des sous-vêtements et des tissus bazins à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est au Nigéria et à Lomé, Etat voisin du Bénin, que Rafiatou achète ses articles. Rafiatou a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit auprès de ALIDé et a bien effectué le remboursement. Face aux exigences de sa clientèle et à leur demande sans cesse croissante, Rafiatou désire renforcer son activité et augmenter son chiffre d'affaire. C'est pourquoi Rafiatou sollicite un second crédit.
texts.en:
R. Rafiatou was born on September 8, 1980 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to AKILOCHO Idrissou and is the mother of one child, who is in school. For seven years, she has been living with her child in the Adogléta district in Cotonou. To provide for herself and her child, Rafiatou sells outfits for children, undergarments, and damask cloth at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She purchases her goods in Lomé and from Nigeria, a country bordering Benin. She has already had an ALIDé loan and has carried out the repayment of it. Facing the requirements of her customers and their ever-growing demands, Rafiatou would like to bolster her business and to increase her sales. This is why she is requesting a second loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying clothing for children, undergarments, and fabrics

loans.name: Lucila

texts.en:
Lucila P. is from the town of Trento. She is 39 years old. Lucila is married and has 3 school-aged children.
She is involved in farming. She and her husband maintain their rice farm. Lucila also manages their sari-sari store located at their house. She sells stuff like sugar, vinegar and many other products. Like other entrepreneurs, she wants to be successful and have a stable income to sustain her family.

Lucila joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucila has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Lucila is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and additional store inventory. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lucila from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and improve their living conditions. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer & seeds for her rice farm  and additional store inventory for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Zungumzo

texts.en:
Zungumzo S. M. is forty years old, married and has four children aged between twelve years and two and a half years old. His business is located along the Likoni-Lunga lunga road which is a busy highway and near the Likoni bus stop in Mombasa. It is well known by the name Z Auto parts. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attraction sites not forgetting the Indian ocean's white beaches. 

Zungumzo sells auto spare parts and also owns a garage in which he serves taxis, Matatu owners and walk ins who have private vehicles. He has been in this business for five years now and he says that this business is profitable. The major challenge that he has is that he lacks machines in his business to enable him to work efficiently and effectively. He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more auto spare parts to sell to his clients and expand his business. He hopes that someday he will diversify into carpentry where he will open a training school and train other young people and make them self-reliant. He says he is very passionate about what he does.

loans.use: Auto spare parts

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina is married with one child who is at school. She also takes care of additional family members. She owns a beauty salon in Kawempe working on all types of hair and providing services including relaxing, plaiting and weaving. 

She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of cosmetics, creams and weaves. She buys boxes of cosmetics from Kampala city shops and uses public transportation to and from shopping. Madina goes shopping once a week. Her customers are mainly women.   

She has done this business for many years now and works seven days a week.  Her main business challenge is transportation from her home to the Kampala city shops.  She aspires to buy a plot of land and build a house for herself. She joined MCDT because of the low interest charged on loans.

Madina resides in and rents a two-room house and the family has access to electricity and no piped water.  Her greatest expense in a month is rent for her house.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cosmetics, creams and weaves

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce J. is currently in the business of selling maize flour, rice, beans and more at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of maize flour and rice to sell.  

Joyce is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has two children, and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store to sell her goods.

loans.use: Stock more bags of maize flour and rice to sell

loans.name: Lucina

texts.en:
Lucina B. is from the town of Trento. She is 42 years old. Lucina is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lucina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Lucina also raises pigs and chickens. She hopes that this new venture of hers will grow as well.

Lucina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Lucina is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and livestock feed. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lucina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and livestock feed

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet, a married mother of four children who are all in school, is a tailor in Nalukolongo. She makes uniforms, sweaters and t-shirts for all schools and individuals in her area. A tailor for many years now and an MCDT client for six years, Harriet works five days a week, and her main challenge is the seasonality of her business. She wants to use this loan to buy more rolls of school materials and threads.

Aspiring to improve her living standards, Harriet joined MCDT because she wanted additional business capital. She resides in and owns a five-roomed house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more rolls of school uniforms and threads

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of 16 sacs of coal

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda A., from the town of Trento, is 46 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Luzviminda owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting rice for sale. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she recently started raising hogs for fattening and sale. She hopes to acquire more pigs to raise.

Luzviminda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from CEVI, she is now requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure as well as livestock feed. This will be Luzviminda's second loan from CEVI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure as well as livestock feed

loans.name: Jonah

texts.en:
Jonah N. N. is 40 years old, married and has five children aged between 7 and 21 years old. His business is located at a busy area in Nairobi called Mukuru Kwa Njenga. The Mukuru Kwa Njenga area is served by the Kitengela branch. 

His business is well-known by the name Smart Furniture Designer. He sells such items as wall units, beds, seats, side boards, tables and stools to the local people, schools and churches. He has been doing this business for 10 years now. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is that there are so many people in the area doing the same business so his customers are not loyal as they are spoiled for choice. He says there is a lot of power rationing, hindering the business' performance, as well as insecurity in the area. 

However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using the loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings to buy timber for making the products that he sells to his customers. He hopes to open a big furniture shop in the future. He describes himself as hardworking and business-oriented.

loans.use: Timber

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Miriam is married with five children, two of whom have completed their education up to the university level. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She changed her business enterprise from a clothing to a banana business. She owns a stall selling bananas. She sells matooke (bananas) and she hopes to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. 

She has done this business for about three months now, because she had previously dealt in clothing. Besides this banana business, she also fries samosas. She sells her bananas in Nalukolongo market; she mainly sells bananas to both men and women. 

Miriam works six days a week and one of the challenges she faces in her business is that bananas are seasonal. Her goals are to expand her business by going to farmers directly and also to start selling on a wholesale basis.  

She decided to work with MCDT because of its good customer care.   

She resides in and rents the house she stays in, and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy bunches of bananas

loans.name: Andrei

texts.en:
Andrei is married with a 5-year-old daughter. He sells women's clothing at the Yulana market in Pavlograd town. Andrei has been in this business for four years. 

He understood quickly that to make this business successful, he needs to offer good quality items in a large assortment. That is why he invested most of his income into his inventory. Today, Andrei's business is the main source of income for his family.

Andrei would like to borrow 9,200 Ukraine Hryvnia to purchase inventory. He needs to increase the assortment of seasonal inventory before the coming fall season.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: David

texts.en:
Most people from western Uganda have embarked on profitable business ventures using savings from their farming and milk-selling businesses. Three years ago, 54-year-old David T. went with this tide and started his retail shop in Burambara-Rukungiri. This business has been, in many ways, his recourse in dealing with the many demands that come with providing for a family and meeting the costs of operating a business. 

David, a happy-go-lucky, married father of five, for the most part sells coffee, beans and ground nuts. In a month, his business generates profits to the sum of 260,000 shillings and with this loan, he wants to buy more retail stock for resale. He specifically wants to buy more beans, ground nuts and rice.

loans.use: Buying more beans, ground nuts and rice for resale

loans.name: Zeesee

texts.en:
Zeesee B. is 45 years old and lives with her husband and four children in their own ger (the traditional nomadic housing tent) in Hovd province, western Mongolia. Her husband is a gardener while her youngest daughter attends a local high school.

Zeesee began her business in 2005 with the help of her daughter and, since then, her business has been stable. With her business earnings she was enabled to rent a stall at a local market and increase the number and variety of her products.

Zeesee is requesting a 1,900,000 MNT loan to purchase a large number of plumbing parts to sell before the upcoming winter season.

loans.use: To purchase a large number of plumbing parts to sell

loans.name: Naboth

texts.en:
A. Naboth is 28 years old and married with three children. He has operated a boda-boda business in Bwamba for four years now. (A boda-boda is a cycle or motorcycle fitted with a tailor-made seat over the rear wheel).

Naboth says that it is the good service that he offers that has helped to increase and retain his customers. He says that his customers are from the local community and most of them are repeat customers and he is able to make 300,000 shillings as monthly profits. He also has a banana plantation from which he is able to produce food both for sale and for home consumption.

Naboth needs a loan to be able to buy a new motorcycle and this will increase his income base. He says that before becoming a boda-boda operator, he was a contractor working for people and now he is grateful that he owns his own business and hopes to increase the number of motorcycles for increased benefits.

loans.use: To buy another motorcycle for increased income

loans.name: Mungunhuu

texts.en:
Mungunhuu B. is 21 years old and lives with his parents and siblings in their own house in Hovd province, western Mongolia.

Mungunhuu operates a transport service in his town which he began in 2006 after purchasing a small car. He has found success with his business and has gained much experience as a driver over the years.

In 2009, Mungunhuu provided transport services to tourists and earned 3,000,000 MNT so now, with the earnings, he wants to purchase a bigger car for his business. He is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a newer and bigger car for his transportation business.

Mungunhuu is an honest and hardworking person who is known by his customers for his good character. For the future he hopes to continue to provide a quality and efficient transportation service.

loans.use: To purchase a newer and bigger car for his transportation business

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is married with eight children and all of them are at school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. She owns a house which has electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses are food, water and electricity.

Monica changed her business enterprise from a food stall to selling alcohol and has been in this business for a few months. She operates her business from her shop and her customers are other traders. She works seven days a week and depends on this job for a living. Her business challenge is thieves.

Monica doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work from delivery vans, which get the gin from Kabarole district.

With the loan, Monica  plans to buy more jerrycans of local gin which she sells retail only. She is aiming to see her business grow big and to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more jerycans of local gin to sell

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George T. is an individual client of Pearl Microfinance from Rukungiri. He is 52 years old and married with eight children, four of whom are still in school. George is in the business of agriculture and has banana plantations. However, as another source of income, he sells coffee, beans, sweet potatoes and cassava that he buys from other farmers and takes to the market. 

George needs a loan to be able to buy manure, mulch and stake poles for his plantations so that they give him better produce. He has been in the farming business for 15 years and he inherited it from his late father. It is because of his hard work that he is where he is right now. 

His plan is to expand his agriculture business and build a permanent house for his family.

loans.use: Buying manure, mulch and stake poles for his plantations so that they give him better produce

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 50-year-old single woman from Lebanon living with her mother and one sister. She has owned a toy shop in her town since 1996 and sells all type of games in addition to kids stories and books. She has been working hard in her store to be able, with the cooperation of her sister, to provide better life conditions for her sick mother. In order to fulfill her business objectives and increase the liquidity of her services, she is asking for a loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.al. to increase her store purchases before the coming holidays because her sales rise during this period and she has to be prepared. Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in her picture, not indicating her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers. About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specializing in Microfinance. At Ameen s.a.l., we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes. Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: Increase her store purchases

loans.name: Kevin

texts.en:
Kevin is married with three children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses includes rent and school fees.

Kevin owns a restaurant in Kawempe selling traditional food and has been in this business for many years. She buys her foodstuffs from Kalerwe market and uses public transport to and from shopping. She sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale, working seven days a week. Her business challenges include thieves and seasonality. She doesn’t have any side business.

Kevin wants to use this loan to buy a deep freezer. She is aspiring to educate her children up to university. She decided to work with MCDT because of its low interest rate.

loans.use: To buy a deep freezer

loans.name: El Hadj

texts.fr: Né en 1974, Monsieur El Hadj S. est un maçon très connu dans la ville de Thiès. Il gagne beaucoup de marché de par ses connaissances et son travail jugé de sérieux par ses clients. Il souhaitait un prêt de 125 000 FCFA  pour acheter des planches de coffrage afin d'augmenter son stock insuffisant de planches. Enfin, Monsieur El Hadj S. est marié et compte sur son métier pour régler tous ses besoins et ceux de sa famille.
texts.en:
Born in 1974, Mr. El Hadj S. is a very well-known mason in the town of Thiès. He wins many contracts because of his experience and the seriousness he displays in his work, according to customers. He is requesting a loan of 125,000 FCFA to buy formwork planking to increase his insufficient stock of planks. Finally, Mr. El Hadj S. is married and relies on his job to cover all of his needs and those of his family.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase construction materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase necessary tools for his shop

loans.name: Samuel

texts.fr:
B. Samuel, née à Kigali  secteur Muhima dans la province de ville de Kigali du Rwanda, il est marié, il a 4 enfants, il a 40 ans, son ainé a 12  ans et son dernier enfant à 5 ans et  son niveau d’éducation est primaire. Il habite à Kicukiro avec sa famille. Tous ces enfants vont à l’école. Son épouse  fait le commerce de détail en  boutique pour aider son mari de faire vivre sa famille et pouvoir améliorer les conditions de vie de celle-ci. Il effectue ce commerce de transport des personnes sur moto a Kigali .Il vient de contracter un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano pour acheter le réservoir de sa moto pour remplacer le vieux réservoir.
Il fait les épargnes, une partie du profit est  épargne pour les études de ses enfants et supporter la capacité  financière de sa femme. Il a pu construire une maison grâce aux épargnes continuelles.
texts.en:
B. Samuel was born in Kigali, in the Muhima sector, in the province of Kigali City, Rwanda. He is married and has four children. He is 40 years old. His eldest child is 12, and his last child is 5. Samuel has a primary school education. He lives with his family in Kicukiro. All of his children go to school. His wife has a retail store to help her husband provide for the family and to be able to improve living conditions. Samuel has a business transporting people on his motorbike in Kigali. He just signed a loan with the micro-finance institution Amasezerano to buy a gas tank for his motorbike to replace the old one. He is saving money. Part of his profit is saved for his children's schooling and for supporting his wife's finances. He was able to build a house, thanks to the steady savings.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying a fuel tank for his motorbike

loans.name: Kweyamba Women's Namawojjolo 2, Lugazi Group

texts.en:
N. Daisy is a 28-year-old mother of one, operating a business selling soft drinks in Nawawojjollo, Lugazi. A friend helped her to start up in business after she prevailed upon her to dispense with the idea of depending wholly on her husband for everything.

Daisy has been running her business for the last two years and, in a sense, has been successful in as far as making her business function well. Her close personal involvement and proactivity in the decision-making processes aimed at helping her business grow, have been her towers of strength. In a week, her business generates her profits that total up to 35,000 shillings.

With this loan, Daisy envisages being in a position to buy more soft drinks and bottled fruit juice for her business. She will resell it to earn more revenue.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks like sodas and bottled fruit juices to sell

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana S. was born in 1966 and lives in Ijevan city with her 13-year-old son. Svetlana's husband has been missing for several years, but she doesn't lose hope of finding him some day!

Since 2005 Svetlana has run her own shop where she sells food, household goods and clothes. With the profit from her business she keeps her small family, supports her business, and also was able to buy a computer.

To increase her income, Svetlana intends to start to manage an Internet club. Thus, now, she asks for a 550,000 AMD loan which will enable her to buy two more computers. Her son has good computer skills so, after his lessons, he will help his mother in her new occupation.

loans.use: To buy two computers for her new Internet business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 23 years old and married, and she has one child. She graduated from primary school. 

The borrower is a tailor. She will use this loan to purchase a domestic sewing machine and cloth. The borrower has had a sewing business for two years and acquired a great deal of experience in her work. The borrower has a good reputation and is capable of attracting many clients.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and cloth

loans.name: Tsedev

texts.en:
Tsedev N. is 38 years old and lives with his wife and two children in their own ger (the traditional housing tent) in Hovd province, western Mongolia. He and his family have been living in Hovd for over three years.

Tsedev and his wife, Bertsetseg, manage a clothing trading business at the local market in their town. They started their business in 2007 and since then they have gained much progress with it. Their earnings have enabled them to buy a new container at the local market from which they sell the clothing.

For the future, Tsedev hopes to use his experience to operate his own clothing store. He wants to sell a wider variety of clothes to meet all of his customers needs. He is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothes to sell at retail prices.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is married with two children. She runs a small business selling women’s clothing in one kiosk and sunflower oil and related products in an adjacent kiosk.

Olga has been in the retail business for eleven years. When she started her business the competition was low. Later she decided to diversify her retail business into two parts – clothing and food. This helped Olga to maintain a steady income despite high competition.

This business is the only source of income for Olga’s family. She would like to obtain a loan of 10,000 UAH to purchase one more kiosk. She hopes to increase her turnover and make additional income.

loans.use: To purchase one more kiosk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To print out language training DVDs and textbooks

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is married with children — all of them in school. She also takes care of additional family members. Rose owns a store at her home in Kanyanya selling charcoal. She buys bags of charcoal from delivery vans at her home and so doesn’t have to pay for transport costs. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. Rose doesn’t incur any rent for her business. Her business challenge is seasonality because she works from a muddy place so when it rains her customers don’t reach out to her. She resides in, and owns, a three-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses includes food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Josiane Clarisse

texts.fr: A. Josiane Clarisse est née le 05 Mars 1969 et vit depuis quarante et un an à Ayélawadjè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Josiane Clarisse est mariée à MICHOZOUNOU Jean, un enseignant. Le couple a quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Josiane Clarisse vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Pour venir en aide à son mari dans les diverses charges du ménage, Josiane Clarisse vend du charbon de bois et de façon secondaire, de l'huile d'arachide à son domicile. Josiane Clarisse a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Dans le but d'élever le niveau de son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, Josiane Clarisse sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Josiane Clarisse A. was born on March 5, 1961; she has been living in the Ayélawadjè district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for 41 years. Josiane Clarisse is married to Jean Michozounou, a teacher. They have four children, all attending school. Josiane Clarisse lives together with her husband and children. To help her husband support the family, Josiane Clarisse sells charcoal and, as a secondary activity, peanut oil out of her home. Josiane Clarisse already received two loans in the past and repaid them well. With the goal of expanding her business and better respond to customer demand, Josiane Clarisse is seeking a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing bags of charcoal and cans of peanut oil

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The borrower is 30 years old, married and has four children. She graduated from a literacy program. 

The borrower is a tailor. She will use this loan to purchase a new sewing machine, an embroidery machine, and cloth. The borrower has a much experience in sewing and a fine reputation in the area. Many clients go to her. 

The borrower has an enormous ambition to develop her business in the future to attract more clients.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine, an embroidery machine, and cloth

loans.name: Lucie

texts.fr:
Lucie Mukarytabana  est une fille de 28 ans, née à Kicukiro - Kigali, province de Kigali du Rwanda. Elle est célibataire, elle a habite a Kicukiro. son niveau d’éducation est primaire

Concernant son activité, elle est commerçante des produits des charbons  à Kigali, elle a une expérience de 5 ans dans ce domaine et. Le crédit contracté avec ACB est  son premier prêt.
Dans l’avenir, elle veut continuer ses études car elle a suspendu en troisième année secondaire par manque du minerval, elle pourra avoir une valeur et se marier ensuite.
texts.en:
Lucie Mukarytabana is a 28-year-old girl who was born in Kicukiro – Kigali, a province of Kigali in Rwanda. She is single and lives in Kicukiro. She has an elementary school education. She sells coal products in Kigali, which she has been doing for 5 years. The loan she has with ACB is her first. In the future, she’d like to continue her studies, because she stopped attending middle school due to lack of funds to pay the fees. She will thus have value and be able to marry.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 16 bags of coal to resell

loans.name: Jacques

texts.fr: Monsieur Jacques F. est un agent de sécurité âgé de 27 ans. Il mène en parallèle de l’élevage de porcs. Ainsi pour développer cette activité, elle souhaitait un prêt de 100 000 FCFA  quelques bêtes. Monsieur Jacques F., célibataire, compte beaucoup sur cette activité pour diversifier et augmenter ses revenus afin de régler ses besoins et ceux de ses proches parents qui attendent beaucoup de lui
texts.en:
Mr. Jacques F., aged 27, is a security guard. Concurrently, he has a business raising pigs. To develop this business, he would therefore like a loan of 100,000 francs CFA for a few animals. Jacques is unmarried and is counting very much on this business to diversify and increase his revenues in order to cover his needs and those of his parents, who expect a lot of him.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying pigs

loans.name: Kweyamba Womens Group 3-Namawojjolo -Lugazi

texts.en: N. Christine, 28, earns her living waiting for travelers to buy bottled fruit juices and chicken from her stand. It is not always a rosy picture! One has to have reserves of resilience to succeed in this business. Anyone who has traversed the Kampala-Jinja highway will bear witness to the stiff competition that exists at this popular stop-over for refreshments. Christine is now four years into this business and says she has managed to give one of her young children an education out of the profits. In a week she makes close to 45,000 shillings, and is anticipating better prospects with the acquisition of this loan. Through the sale of more bottled soft drinks and roast chicken she will be able to earn more money.

loans.use: Buy more bottled soft drinks and roast chicken to sell

loans.name: Mukono Womens Crafts Enterprise Group

texts.en:
Faith N. is 57 years old, still energetic, resourceful, agile, focused and down to earth. Despite her single status at her late age, she has not wavered in her dreams and aspirations of improving the livelihood and welfare status of her family. With a lot of  wisdom, forethought and experience to bank on, for the last five years she has been making significant and steady strides in her local crafts-selling business in Butebe-Mukono.  

Having obtained her niche in the local market with 200,000 shillings as weekly profits, she is now taking a long view, anticipating that she will in the future be able to export some of her local crafts, such as mats, baskets and chairs. Her customers cut across from travelers to university students and family people. 

Faith is proud of her five children with only one still in school. It is the reason why she views their education as an invaluable responsibility that she has to shoulder by all means necessary. With this loan, she wants to purchase more raw materials like sisal and bamboo to make more chairs, mats and baskets.

loans.use: The purchase of raw materials for making her products, like sisal and bamboo

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more fufu, rice and oil to sell

loans.name: Médoune

texts.fr: Monsieur Médoune D. est à sa troisième demande de prêt. Il sollicitait un montant de 400 000 FCFA. C’est un grand commerçant et gère son propre magasin sis en face Hôpital Thiès. Il vend des matériels électroniques, des matelas et divers produits. Avec ce prêt, Monsieur D.  âgé de 32 ans veut renforcer son commerce en achetant beaucoup de produits.
texts.en:
M. Médoune D. is asking for his third loan, in the amount of CFA 400,000. He has his own store across from the hospital in Thiès, selling electronics, mattresses and other goods. With this loan he plans to grow his business, increasing his inventory greatly.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build inventory of a variety of products

loans.name: Prosperity Group

texts.en:
Oretha S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called “Prosperity”. She is 32 years old, is married and has three children who range from 5 to 15 years old. Oretha was only able to attend school through 10th grade due to lack of financial support.

For six years, Oretha has been selling palm oil, rice, onions, tomatoes and beans in Chicken Soup Factory Market, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

Oretha plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more gallons of palm oil, rice, onions, salt and beans. She describes herself as a devoted woman. Her goal is to improve her business, build a house, and continue to educate her children.

in the photo that accompanies this profile, Esther is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more gallons of palm oil, rice, onions, salt and beans to sell

loans.name: Ubumwe Group

texts.fr:
Jacqueline N. est une commerçante âgée de 30 ans qui habite la Commune urbaine de Musaga en Mairie de Bujumbura. Elle fait le commerce de produits vivriers de boutique comme le riz, le haricot, et autres articles  au marché de Musaga depuis 2003. Elle a fait ses études primaires jusqu’en 6e année. Elle a aussi fait une formation artisanale en cuisine sanctionnée par un Diplôme. Son mari, Eric N. est un chauffeur mais exerce aussi  le commerce d’huile de palme en provenance du Sud- Est du Burundi dans la ville appelée Rumonge.Jacqueline vend ce produit à coté des articles de boutique qu’elle vend aux clients. Elle était employée de Restaurant avant de commencer cette activité. Elle arrive au 12e cycle dans le crédit communautaire avec Turame. 

Elle  est mère de 3 enfants ; 2 filles et un garçon âgés respectivement de 12ans, 7ans et 4ans.
  
Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  acheter de grandes quantités des produits vivriers de boutique mais aussi varier son business en achetant des pommes de terre à l’intérieur du pays pour les revendre aux clients. Elle espère qu’avec du bénéfice généré de ce crédit dans le futur, elle sera à mesure d’acheter une parcelle pour construire sa propre maison,  assurer la scolarité de ses enfants et être une grande commerçante qui travaille avec son propre capital. 

 Elle est une des membres du groupe  communautaire« Ubumwe ».
texts.en:
Jacqueline N. is a 30 year-old shop-keeper who lives in the urban commune of Musaga in the town of Bujumbura. She has sold food products such as rice, beans etc at the Musaga market since 2003. She studied up to sixth grade, and took a cooking apprenticeship for which she was awarded a diploma. Her husband, Eric N. is a driver, but also sells palm oil from the south-east of Burundi in a town called Rumonge. Jacqueline sells this alongside her other products. She worked in a restaurant before setting up her business. She is on the 12th cycle of a community credit programme with Turame. She is the mother of three children - two girls and a boy, aged 12, 7 and 4, respectively. She is seeking a Kiva loan in order to purchase large quantities of food products, but also to diversify her business by buying potatoes from inland to sell to customers. She hopes to use the profits earned in order to purchase her own plot of land in future where she may build her own house, in order to see to her children's schooling and also to become a successful businesswomen who works with her own capital. She is a member of the 'Ubumwe' community group.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase large quantities of food products, but also to diversify her business by purchasing potatoes from inland to sell to her customers

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchasing a carpet frame

loans.name: Faith In Christ Group

texts.en:
Janneh A., who is holding the sign, is the leader of Faith in Christ Group. She is 25 years old and has a 4-year-old child. Janneh completed the 10th grade before leaving school when she had her child.

Janneh sells drinks, fried fish, and chicken at New Georgia Junction. She began her business six years ago when her mother gave her 2,000 Liberian dollars. Her goal is to expand her business to include other areas of town.

loans.use: To buy oil, flour, and coal for her business

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 35-year-old married man with four kids from Lebanon and has been working with scrap iron and haberdashery since 2006. Mohamad requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to do the necessary maintenance on his pickup in order to keep it safe as long as he needs it. This is Mohamad’s fifth loan with Al Majmoua; in the last four cycles he has maintained a good credit record and never missed any payment.

loans.use: To do the necessary maintenance on his pickup

loans.name: Kuwoe Group

texts.en:
Sarah S., shown holding the sign, is the leader of Kuwoe Group. This 36-year-old mother of six children between the ages of 2 and 16, several of whom are enrolled in school from kindergarten to sixth grade, completed the sixth grade before Liberia's Civil War interrupted her education and she began having children.

Sarah sells a variety of personal-use products such as lotion, hair care products, and baby care products at the New Georgia Junction. She began her business eight years ago using 5,000 Liberian Dollars that her friends gave her. She will use her 4,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 21,000 Liberian Dollar loan to purchase additional inventory to sell including lotion, hair products, deodorant, and slippers.

Sarah's goal is to build a shop, buy land, and educate all of her children.

loans.use: To purchase personal hygiene products, baby care products, and slippers to sell

loans.name: Kindé Yvette

texts.fr: A. Kindé Yvette est née en 1967 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin. Yvette est veuve et mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Il y a près de dix sept ans que Yvette habite le quartier Akpakpa à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, avec ses enfants. Yvette a un autre enfant à sa charge, en plus de ses enfants. Yvette vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule ses différentes charges. Pour y arriver, Yvette prépare et vend de la nourriture (pâte de maïs et riz accompagné de sauce) à Cotonou. Yvette s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Yvette exerce cette activité depuis une dizaine d'année et a déjà bénéficié de quatre crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Face à l'accroissement de sa clientèle, Yvette désire rehausser le niveau de son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Kindé Yvette A. was born in 1967 in Ouidah, an historic town in Benin. Yvette is a widow with three school-aged children. She has lived in the Akpakpa quarter of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, with her children for almost 17 years. She has another child in her care as well as her own, and sees to their needs by herself. To do so, she prepares and sells food (corn and rice with sauce) in Cotonou. Yvette sources her goods from Dantokpa, Benin's international market, and has been in this line of work for around ten years. She has already received four loans which have all been successfully repaid. In light of rapid growth in her customer base, Yvette wishes to boost her business proposition and better satisfy those customers.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn, rice, and condiments and sauce

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more palm oil, rice, onions, tomatoes, pepper, salt and beans to sell

loans.name: Gertrude Matilde

texts.fr:
femme de 40ans,mariée et mère 4 enfants dont l'âge varie de 20ans à 5ans et dont 4 sont scolariser. ayant un niveau secondaire et ayant 8 personnes à charge elle se lança dans le commerce d'alimentation en 2001 avec un capital de 50000.Son revenu moyen est de 100000frs par jour.
Avec ce prêt elle compte renforcer son activité en achetant des cartons de bôite de lait, boîte de conserve(exeter,bull boeuf,rio),pâte alimentaire,sucre,friandise,jus de fruit(ceres) et d'autres produits de premiers necessité.
pour l'avancement de son activité elle épargne tout les jours,à avoir un bon acceuil,s'efforce à avoir un bon étallage et cela en dépit de la hausse des prix des marchandises sur le marché.
son ambition est d'avoir une gande boutique si possible en avoir plusieurs dans la ville afin d'être grossiste dans les jours futurs.
son plus grand rêve est d'améliorer les conditions de vie de ses enfants afin qu'il poursuivent leur études et s'aqurir d'un terrain. dans son quartier estune bonne femme.
texts.en:
This lady is a 40 year-old married mother of four, whose children are aged 5 to 20, and four of whom attend school. Having completed secondary education and with 8 dependents, she entered the food retail business in 2001 with initial capital of 50,000 FRS. Her daily revenue is now 10,000 FRS. She aims to use this loan to boost her business by purchasing boxes of milk, jars of jam (exeter, bull beef and rio), pasta, sugar, biscuits, fruit juice and other staple foods. She saves money every day in order to help grow her business and so that she will have a good display of goods for potential customers, despite a rise in prices. Her goal is to have a large shop, and if possible eventually several others in the town, so that she can be a wholesaler in future. Her dream is to improve her children's living conditions so that they can continue their studies, and also to buy a plot of land. She is seen as a good woman in her quarter.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of biscuits, jars of jam, milk and sugar

loans.name: Bossou

texts.fr: Née en Avril 1977, BOSSOU A. vit depuis trente trois ans au quartier Xwlacodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. A. est mariée à ANATO Vincent, un couturier. Le couple a quatre enfants à charge, dont trois sont leurs propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés et vivent ensemble avec leurs parents à Xwlacodji. Les charges de la famille sont assurées ensemble par le couple. A. n'a pas fréquenté l'école, mais a appris la coiffure. A. a son atelier de coiffure situé dans son quartier et y vend également divers produits de coiffure. A. achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu antérieurement six crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. A. désire agrandir davantage son atelier et mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle A. sollicite un autre prêt. Plus tard, A. envisage acquérir une parcelle.
texts.en:
A. Bossou was born in April,1977, and for 33 years has lived in the Xwlacodji neighborhood of Cotonou, Benin's economic capital. She is married to Vincent Anato, a tailor. They care for four children, including three of their own. All the children have been to school and still live with the family in Xwlacodji. Together, the couple pays for the family's expenses. A. didn't go to school, but learned hairdressing. She has a neighborhood salon, and also sells hair care products that she buys at Dantokpa, Benin's international trade center. She has repaid six previous loans from ALIDé. A. wants to increase the size of her salon so she can better meet customer demand. For that reason, she's asking for another loan. In future, she plans to buy a building lot.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy hair care products

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchasing sewing materials and a new machine

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is married to a taxi driver with whom she has eight children; only four of her children go to school.  She doesn’t take care of additional family members.  She sells cold drinks in Mulago market. She sells cold drinks like soda, orange juice, passion fruit juice and water. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.  

Aisha has been in this business for over five years.  She wants to use this loan to buy more baskets of passion fruit, oranges, crates of soda and boxes of mineral water. She sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale. She buys these baskets of oranges and passion fruit from Kalerwe market and uses motorcycles to and from shopping.  Crates of soda and boxes of mineral water are bought at her place of work by delivery vans.  Her business challenge is the rainy season. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow big so that she can get enough profit to buy another plot of land.  

Aisha decided to join MCDT because she wanted capital to start her business.  Aisha resides in and owns a four-roomed house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water.  Her monthly expenses includes food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more crates of soda,  boxes of mineral water, and baskets of oranges and passion fruit

loans.name: Patrick Arnaud Gildas

texts.fr:
Jeune commercant de 36 ans, apres ses etudes universitaires a l'obtention de sa licence en economie, il se lance dans le commerce des Poissons de mer fumes, comme les Harengs et Maquerelles.
Avec la somme de 50000frs une partie de sa bourse quand il etait etudiant, il achete 2 cartons de poissons fumes et loue une table et commence a vendre dans le grand marche de brazzzaville, chose etrange , le poisson fume dans ce marche n'est vendu que par les femmes.
il se fait plusieurs clients , parcequ'il etait le seul homme, et par jour il peut vendre 80000 a 100000frs parceque ce genre de poisson fume est tres apprecie par les habitants du Congo , tres moins chere et disponible pour toute les couches de la populations.
Avec ce pret il pense acheter 50 cartons de harengs et 10 de maquerelles, puisqu'il s'approvisionne chez les Beninois qui font la peche a Pointe -Noire, et chaque semaine il doit envoyer de l'argent pour avoir du poisson au lieu de cela il fera ses commandes au moins deux fois le mois.
Il pense lui meme dans peu de temps acheter beaucoup en se faisant fournisseurs aupres des vendeuses du marche et faire aussi la vente en detail en meme temps.Tres aimable tout le monde l'appelle papa gentil
texts.en:
This young 36-year-old merchant, who obtained a degree in Economics upon completing his university studies, started a business selling smoked fish such as herring and mackerel. Using 50,000 francs of his scholarship money from when he was a student, he bought two boxes of smoked fish, rented a table, and started selling at the great market of Brazzaville. Oddly, smoked fish is typically sold only by women at this market. Being the only man involved in this activity, he got many customers. He was able to achieve sales of 80,000 to 100,000 francs per day as the people of Congo really appreciate this type of smoked fish, and because it is much more affordable and available to all segments of the population. With this loan, he plans to buy 50 boxes of herring and 10 boxes of mackerel. He gets his stocks from the Beninese, who fish in Pointe-Noire, and each week he has to send money to get fish. Otherwise, he places orders at least twice a month. In the short term, he plans to increase his stocks of smoked fish and become a supplier for the ladies who sell it at the market, while continuing with his own sales. He is very likable and everyone calls him “papa gentil” (nice daddy).

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 50 boxes of smoked fish such as herring and mackerels

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida is married with six children, and all her children go to school.  She also takes care of additional family members.  She owns a stall  at her home in Bwaise, selling bananas and charcoal. She buys bunches of bananas from delivery vans which get them from villages of Masaka.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas and bags of charcoal. 

Farida first dealt only in bananas but with  additional loans from MCDT, she started investing in charcoal.    She works in a semi-urban area of Bwaise in Kawempe Division, Kampala district. She has been in this banana business for over six years.    Besides this banana business she has rental rooms. 

Farida works seven days a week.  Her business challenges are thieves and seasonality.   She is aspiring of seeing her business grow big and starting going to farmers in Masaka district. She decided to work with MCDT because she wanted additional capital.  Farida resides in and owns a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water.   Her monthly expenses includes food and school fees

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas and bags of charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 44-year-old married man with three school-age children. He has many years of experience working as a car electrician and car electronics seller. And in 2003, he opened his own shop in his town to earn his own profit. After opening his shop, he noticed that his family economic situation was improved and he’s thankful for this. He has taken a first loan and he has been a reliable borrower, with on-time repayments throughout his loan cycle. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase more car electronics equipment in order to grow his business into other areas. Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture, not indicating his name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.
